comments.author: TKOC

description.text: This is a tray for holding and more importantly orienting SMD components. For components on tape, when a tape feeder is not used, this solves the registration problem. Components will be in the same place every time, so the operator doesn't have to reprogram the PnP to find a semi-randomly placed tape.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Fine

Infill:

None

Notes:

This may be one of the larger things you will make, so give the base extra time to heat up and maybe a new coat of hair spray. If the edges or corners start to lift, stop and start over as the final result must be completely flat.
Because of the fine pins, I find setting the extruder about 10deg hotter than normal.

Fragile - Be careful

The small "pins" protruding from the base plate are fragile. There can be debris from the extruder which needs to be removed but this must be done VERY carefully lest the pins are also removed.

FreeCad

This was designed for a Neoden 4. The tray goes on the magnetic bars which sit on the steel plate on the left side of the machine. It accommodates nine 8mm component strips and 16 ICs or other large components. If you have more components, print a second tray and place it behind (further on Y axis) the first tray.

The design was done in FreeCad and I slice with Repetier.

When using the tray, tape it into position on the PnP to prevent it wandering about. I take about 0.5" (10-30mm) piece of masking tape and roll it so it has adhesive all the way round the outside. The roll should be about 5mm diameter or smaller. Place the tape in the channel which will hold a strip of component tape and press it flat. Do not allow the tape to interfere with the side walls of the tray. Place a strip of component tape in the channel.

AFTER all the tapes are in place, On The PnP Machine, carefully remove the protective clear film from the strips.

Check alignment on the PnP machine.

I hope this tray helps solve the registration problem for you!

Remix of: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:445768

Original model was scaled, Orientation aligned to ground planes for supportless printing, I removed all the interior surfaces and cavities, reworked every tooth and skin texture and generally tried to clean up the model to increase ease of printing. It was quite a learning curve as this is my first project working with MeshMixer.

I love the idea of using marbles or ball bearings for the eyes of creatures so I added eye sockets. If properly printed, the "eyes" should just snap in. You can test different size eyes by just printing an eye socket and scaling the model if needed. Previous test attempts show that scaling it 164% for 0.625" dia marbles work well - but I have not tried it with this file. Always measure the marbles prior to printing as they have huge variances, hence why I like using Ball Bearings.

Gator_375_eyes.stl is for 3/8" (0.375) diameter eyes.

description.text:
Significantly increases volume of recorded sound from the direction it's pointed in. My phone app measured average dB of radio news at 50 without the parabola and 56 with it. Just as importantly, it greatly reduces sound capture not coming from the intended direction. The effect is a far greater ability to discern the intended sounds.

Designed for this lapel mic: http://a.co/1vnyzRc
...but will probably work with any lapel mic.

You will want to slide the arm in and out until you find the best focal point for your mic. Then tighten in place with an M3 screw. You'll also need three M3 10mm screws to attach the handle.

Feel free to edit your own version. Those with large printers could make a truly impressive device: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jyTTYqwkgOV

title: Zesty Nimble Smart Effector mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
17/12/2017: Update. This did not work. I've found an unexpected problem. It interferes with the Z-probing sensitivity. I think it is because of the PTFE tube. This is just the right length under the Nimble so when the probe tries to raise the PCB relative to the Nimble it has to compress the PTFE tube and the Z-probe fails to trigger. Removing the PTFE tube helps but of course introduces other issues! :-) I'm therefore terminating this experiment as a failure. If there was any improvement in print quality is was tiny anyway!

I'm leaving it here in the hope that someone may be able to overcome this problem and continue development - but I don't plan to do any more work on it.

16/12/2017: After happily using the Zesty Nimble mount for the Smart Effector designed by Lykle for some time, (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2453322 ) I read a report of someone who felt that the Nimble mount was causing unwanted movement of the nozzle.

Intrigued by the idea I designed this mount to isolate any movement of the Nimble from the PCB and thus from the nozzle. This is only to test and I do not expect major print improvements or anything - the Nimble / Smart Effector combination prints very well anyway.

The logic of the potential movement goes like this:

  • there is a flexi PCB, designed with some flex for the Z-probe
  • there is a potential for horizontal force from the resistance to movement that the flex drive cable has - even inertia
  • the flex drive cable is about 40mm above the PCB so the lever is about 40mm long
  • any horizontal movement will be transferred to the heatsink and nozzle through the Nimble, PCB, heatsink, nozzle chain
  • the nozzle is about 50mm below the PCB so any movement at the top of the Nimble would be amplified about 25%
  • any deviation of the nozzle from the intended position could contribute to lower print quality

I say again, though, I'm not trying to solve a problem, this is experimental and if there is an improvement it is likely to be small so there is no reason not to use Lykle's mount.

Having said that, this one is a finished product and is mounted on my printer at present - and is printing very well indeed.

title: NEMA 17 stepper motor cooler for 40mm fan (even for helloBEEprusa)

description.text:
I build the cooler cap with Sketchup for my helloBEEprusa, because the stepper motors got alarming hot when I printed on higher speeds. But it will fit on any NEMA 17 Stepper as this is a standard size. The thing is optimized for easy airflow and has a build in safety limit so that it is impossible to push the cap too near to the back of the stepper.
The design regards the FFF process and the tolerance is made for a tight fit so that no glue or screw is needed.
I tried to reduce the amount of filament needed to a minimum so the walls are as thin as possible. This supports the flexibility of the PETG to get the cap onto the back of the stepper.

Printer:

helloBEEprusa

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,1mm or 0,2mm

Infill:

50% - 100%

Notes:

I do not recommend to use PLA, as the Stepper might get very hot and PLA will get soft then.
I used PETG from extrudr to print it and it works as it should. You can use ABS or BDP too.
I printed it with 40mm/s and the result was great.
As the grid dimension is 5mm, I recommend printing in 0,2mm or 0,1mm. 0,3mm won't fit and you will not get right results.

title: Trogdor the Clipinator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Trogdor!!!

Everybody's favorite Burninator is finally putting those beefy arms to good use. Don't let Trogdor the Clipinator's tiny size fool you, with PLA at 50% infill he can hold at least 4.5kg / 10lbs (I was surprised too)! This dragon-man is perfect for stringing up lights, attaching things to nails, clipinating the countryside, etc.

Slim, Thick, and Slim-Spikeless versions included. Clip teeth have 0.6mm vertical separation, with plenty of room to scale up for larger applications.

Arm and wing for decoration and to hold during clip placement. May have sharp spikes. Does not have legs or eyebrows. Does not breathe fire. Unclear effect on peasants or thatched-roof cottages.

Glowforge ready to print.

I have a bunch of Tiles that have failing batteries in them, so I ordered a bunch of replacements from Digi-Key. The rather scammy nature of the Tile’s construction (Soldered battery, and ultrasonically welded, tough as a Tick case) means you have to destroy the case to replace the battery.

Digi Key part number CR-2032/VCN P660-ND

I was going to 3D print one, but have this laser sitting behind me, and some proof grade…

From 3mm Acrylic cut the middle disk that houses electronics.

From 1MM Maple veneer (with 3M adhesive backing) cut:
1 top.
The red dot is where you push the veneer to activate the tile. The small dot in the keyhole is placed over the switch inside the case to activate the button when the cover is pressed. I used the adhesive on the veneer to hold it over the button, but Kapton tape was my second choice
1 bottom.
This is the large round disk with the 3 speaker holes

1 "Shim” layer
(The same profile as the 3MM acrylic).
2 Board shims
Fit inside the compartment to hold the board and speaker

title: Quick and Easy Gift Tags
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a (relatively) quick and easy gift tag that you can add to your Christmas gifts this year to add that special spark.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

This goes without saying, but... print the holly leaves in green, the berries in red, and the tag itself in white. Or, be a rebel and create your own color scheme!

The print layer must be set to 0.2mm or less for this to print correctly.

If you use Cura as your slicer, I highly recommend that you enable the [ Ironing ] feature. This adds a little bit of time to the print process, but it makes the top surface perfectly smooth. Doing this allows you to write on the tag with a Sharpie without the ink bleeding between the lines, as you can see. I tried one without ironing and the letters looked like they were in a cartoon rush!

I purposely modeled this so that the holly leaves and the berries can be positioned anywhere as opposed to having a preset indented, location.

  • The quickest way to assemble these is with hot glue.
  • The leaves are fragile at the point where they intersect, so be gentle until mounted.
  • Be sure that the leaves are mounted with the stem line facing up.
  • The berries will only properly fit one way into the leaves. Note the rotation before gluing.
  • Place one small dot of hot glue on the tag and then gently press the leaves and the berries onto that drop.
  • Any excess glue can be pulled off easily once it's cooled. Trying to clean it up while it's still hot will only create a mess!

I am still trying to get a grip on blender, so this model was a mashup. I could not figure out how to create the freehand shape needed for the leaf in blender, so I modeled that in Sketchup and then imported that into blender. From there, the rest of the model was done in blender.

author: ZaYAC-ua

description.text:
This is a Remix of the Firefly Serenity.

Difference between original and remake:

  • Size: 50 cm scaled up to 75 cm
  • Made it hollow
  • Added Door from Storm Eagle
  • Added Pilots with cutouts for 5 mm LED
  • Print the pilots and the guns in 0,1 mm cause of better details, rest in 0,2 mm
  • Added Turrets (Front solid, Middle part are 360 degree rotatable, maybe dremel out for clearance (ca. 1/10 mm) or print it with 102%). When you dremel you can adjust the clearence as needed, with the 102% no grinding with dremel but turrets maybe have too much clearence and don´t hold in position)
  • Added modified Legs from Spider Tank (in the original the maker glued the legs and they are not moveable or detachable)
  • You need 6 legs for the ship. Take the version you want. The same as with the turrets. Dremel out the holes (ca. 1/10mm) to get the clearance you want.
  • The front is one part, the other parts need to be mirrored to get the other side.
    Waiting for my new CR-10 Mini and over Christmas i have homeoffice nightshift, so more than enough time.
  • I will upload also Versions with Cutouts for build in LED Strip. Check the list for parts with "LED Cutout". Intention is to make a new headlamp for the living room.
  • When you wanna use the Legs in the Cutout Version, you have to drill your holes through the main part to get the cable inside. Sorry forgot that, but that should not be a big problem with the dremel.

Das ist ein Remix der Firefly Serenity.

Unterschied zwischen Original und Remake:

  • Größe: 50 cm vergrößert auf 75 cm
  • Innen hohl gemacht
  • Tür ergänzt von Storm Eagle
  • Waffen ergänzt (Vorne fest, Middle part sind 360 Grad drehbar, entweder nach dem Druck leicht ausdremeln (ca. 1/10mm) oder mit 102% drucken. Mit der Dremel Variante könnt Ihr euch selbst den Freiraum bestimmen, mit der gedruckten Variante kein Dremeln doch könnten die Waffen sich dann frei bewegen. Halten im schlimmsten Fall nicht mehr die Position.)
  • Modifizierte Beine vom Spider Tank (im original hat der Maker die Beine angeklebt und sind nicht beweglich/abnehmbar)
  • Piloten ergänzt mit Aussparungen für 5 mm LED
  • Piloten und Guns in 0,1 mm drucken wegen besserer Details und den Rest in 0,2 mm
  • Ihr braucht 6 Beine für das Schiff. Sucht euch einfach eine der vier Versionen aus. Hier gilt dasselbe wie bei den Geschützen. Dremelt die Löcher (ca. 1/10mm) bis zur gewünschten Freigängigkeit.
  • Front ist ein Teil, die anderen Teile müsst Ihr spiegeln um die Gegenseite zu erhalten.
  • Ich habe noch eine Version "LED Cutout" hoch geladen. Viel Spaß beim löten. Die Idee dahinter ist eine neue Deckenlampe für das Wohnzimmer.
  • Wenn Ihr die Beine/Legs in der Cutout Version verwenden wollt, müsst Ihr in den Rumpf eure Löcher zur Durchführung des Stromkabels bohren. Sollte aber kein Problem sein mit einem Dremel. Hab ich leider vergessen aus zu schneiden.

Warte auf meinen neuen CR-10 Mini und über Weihnachten Nachtschicht im Homeoffice, daher mehr als genug Zeit.

description.text:
The Pulse 15e is an outstanding airplane! I love to put the landing gear into tricycle configuration then take off and land over and over and over . . .
The pulseski.stl model has thin skis (as seen in the picture). They are nice and flexible but I have not tested them yet.
The pulseski2.stl model skis are twice was thick in case the thin ones are not string enough.
A rubber band keeps the ski tips up.
The box of the ski limits how far forward and backward the skis can rotate.
I will update as soon as I get some snow.
After you print them, dip the the tips into very hot water for a few seconds, then form them with a slight upward angle. You can use the slight upward curve of the edge of a dinner plate.
I have also included the sketchup file.
The bolt that holds the wheel will l be recycled to hold the ski.
Its only $139 PNP
https://www.horizonhobby.com/product/storefronts/plug-n-play/rc-outlet/pulse-14m-pnp-fcef28000
Update 12/31/2017 No surprise here, but the skis do not work in powder. There needs to be an ice shell on top of the snow, or a road under a thin layer of powder.
Update 1/20.2018 The thin skis work great! https://youtu.be/Wy4-OzdzrBQ

Keep in mind that you'll need to push down on the button in both directions as it slides to work the mechanism.

author: Dragunov9999

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:243650 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=243650

Why

I bought a horizontal bar to hang my (empty) camera bags from, but forgot to buy the hooks that go with it.
Rather than go back to the store I spent way more time designing and printing the hangers myself.

I ended up printing mine with PETG at 60% size, 3 perimeters, 15% infill and 3 top/bottom layers and they hold up just fine.

Features

  • Can accomodate a 40mm diameter bar at 100% scale
  • Designed for strength (chamfered edges make it stronger...I think)
  • Can be scaled up or down in your slicer to accomodate other bar sizes
  • Shaped like an "S" (I'm really stretching the features here)

Instructions

  • Print it in PETG with multiple walls and slow speed to get the strongest part.
  • Print without a fan to get the strongest part.
  • No supports required
  • Prints fine at 0.3mm layer height, but lower heights should work just as well.

Open Source

As always the original design file (fusion360) is included, so feel free to improve it (or learn from it)!

description.text:
This is a 3d printable functional guiro (percussion instrument). It is printed in 3 parts. The biggest part is 161mm tall and 111mm diameter. I have included a measured drawing in case you are unsure if it will fit in your printer. Mine was printed in PLA, and I see no reason to use any other material.

The guiro sounds fine, and can be loud enough to cut through an 80 person wind band.

I have included the fusion 360 file as well as a STEP file if you feel like changing the design. However the fusion file is likely to break if you change it, because fusion for some reason does not always recognize all the surfaces even if they did not change.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Supports should only be required for the holes and for the inside of the top part. I printed it with 4 wall layers to make sure it is durable. The orientation for each piece should be obvious from the model, however I have included renders of each individual piece in the appropriate orientation just in case.

For the best glue up, tape a piece of 80-120 grit sand paper to a flat surface. Put the mating surface of the parts on the sandpaper, and rotate them until the surface is rouged up and flat. Apply superglue to one surface, and use an extra pair of hands and eyes to align the parts. It helps to align one edge first, then tip the part down.

title: Front LCD mount for CTC Prusa i3

description.text: Here is a front mounted LCD mount for a CTC Prusa i3. This fit the one that I bought in 2017, so there could be tolerance variables with different year model's because who knows the level of quality control/consistency the company has. I made it to be pressure mounted on the front nuts of the Y axis so that it can be easily removed to adjust the Y axis belt tensioner that came with the printer. I did this so that the mount that came with the printer could not get in the way of the bowden tubing running from the upper left z axis top plate. It also is more stable and looks a hell of a lot better in my opinion.

author: GunnerAlpha

description.text:
This is a spindle speed timing disc for the 52mm Quiet Cut Spindle that is sold by Inventables for the Shapeoko, Shapeoko 2, and X-Carve CNC machines. The disc is designed to be press fit onto the top of the spindle, and has a single slot.

https://www.inventables.com/technologies/quiet-cut-spindle

I used a motor speed sensor module that I bought from Solarbotics.com
https://solarbotics.com/product/29196/

Press fit the disc onto you spindle, mount the sensor module so that the emitter and receiver will be triggered properly when the slot is between them, and connect to your favorite microcontroller. I am using one of my own Electric Imp (imp002) module breakout boards. This module has a pulse counter feature which makes programming this device extremely simple.

This is an extremely simple print. I used Cura and an Ultimaker 3 Extended.

title: Intake funnel/tract for hotend cooling fan, Prusa i3 mk2s

description.text:
An intake funnel/tract for the hotend cooling fan of the Prusa i3 mk2s.
By gradually decreasing the cross-sectional area towards the fan and ducting the air into the fan blades, the performance of the fan increases. The funnel is cut on one side so it doesn't hit the leadscrews when the printer homes.

It consists of 2 parts: The main part is the funnel which bolts on the outside of the fan and the secondary part is a cover that closes the holes in the fan that is needed for the bolts. The cover clicks into the bolts and sits in place by itself.

The funnel can be printed without support but the cover needs support. The funnel should be printed with the flat side down.

Edit: I noticed that I initially uploaded the wrong version of the cover. V2 is the one I have on but a part of it broke off while it printed and I thought it looked nice, so I added a cutout to V3 which is similar to the part that broke off of mine.

I've added a V2 of the funnel so it is made to be as big as possible with the backside in place while still allowing the x endstop to be reached. The backside is a dome held in place on the hotend side of the fan to improve the airflow after the fan.

description.text:
I made these tank mounts for a 1977 Kawasaki KZ650 I am restoring. The bike was a basketcase so I did not even have the original rubber tank mounts to copy so I made some based on measurements I took. They fit on the frame tight, so I had to sand out the inside to get them to fit snug. I didn't want them to fall off when removing the tank, nor did I want them to rattle while riding.

As always, if you make one, all I ask is that you please share a photo or at least comment on how it worked for you!

Am using a TUSH-style filament spool holder (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2706687) which apparently works TOO well, as it allows the spool to rotate backwards as well as forwards (when the extruder retracts).

This rocking motion causes the filament to become loose and unwound - sometimes causing the filament to form a knot and seize up.

The filament guide keeps the filament from whipping around and I quite liked the ball-joint ones, as it allows full 360 degree motion (well its a cool design too!)

I've remixed this one to fit a 2040 aluminium extrusion and be 40mm from the rail

title: Protein Skimmer *Paragon Bubble KING*
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A protein skimmer, designed for an aquarium 800-1500L, for working with a Jebao/Jecod DC3000/4000 pump.
Dimensions of skimmer, 249mm / 323mm / 637mm (H), working level about 250mm counting from the bottom of the base.
I'm adding all the files need to print in full on a 3D printer, but I recommend using acrylic tubes for a better effect, I used a transparent PETG filament for printing the cabinet and parts, and TPU filament for printing seals, below a list of items needed:

  1. Acrylic tube about diameter 200mm and thickness 3mm, lenght 300mm (or you can print from folder Plexi_Acryl file A_3
  2. Acrylic tube about diameter 200mm and thickness 3mm, lenght 150mm (or you can print from folder Plexi_Acryl file A_1
  3. Acrylic tube about diameter 100mm and thickness 2,5mm, lenght 200mm (or you can print from folder Plexi_Acryl file A_2
  4. Printed Area minimum 250mm/302mm and high 202,5mm, (for smaller printers, I divided the base file B_20 in folder Split_Version then need Printed Area 250mm/232mm)
  5. Glue ( I recomender ACRIFIX 192)
  6. Silicon for aquarium
  7. Pomp Jebao DC 3000, or DC 4000

I used about 2,5 kg of PETG filament for printing, and about 120 grams of TPU filament, I used a 30-100% filling depending on the model, nozzle 0.4mm layer high 0.2mm, the total printing time was about 200 hours of printer work:) ...

If you have any questions or problems with the print, please write have a nice print :)

  1. A1-A3 - Plexi
  2. B1-B27 - Body PETG
  3. C1-C7 - Seals TPU

Protein Skimmer Test (salinity 1.025) power on minimum :)

  • https://youtu.be/9ySJQs9baqI

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hgLL9Ly13BO
Replacement for the flimsy clamp base that comes with many swing-arm style desk lamps.

• Throw away your flimsy clamp base but save all other parts.
  • Print part with reasonable fill since it will experience a fair amount of force (I used 40% fill with 3 perimeters).
  • Glue thin (1/16" or so) neoprene foam to bottom of base to keep it from sliding.
  • Attach parts saved from step 1 to base, install clamp onto desk, and install lamp onto clamp.
  • Enjoy your beefy new desk lamp clamp base.
    • Included FreeCAD file to make derivatives easier. The hole sizes, in particular, may need to be adjusted to fit your hardware.

print_settings.Notes:: You'll need some screws, but I think you can figure that out. You can rotate this whichever way works for you.

description.text:
This is a simple adapter to mount a 50mm radial blower onto a 40mm axial fan mount. Used this to mount a blower onto my Monoprice Maker Select V2.1.

It's a bit of a hack job and not that pretty, but it seems to work okay. Printed with something heat tolerant works best.

Update: V2 has a little notch, so the arm has clearance for the mounting bar on my printer when mounted pointing up.

IMPORTANT: Measure the nozzle of your blower. If it is 19.1 x 15 mm this should work for your. I just bought a new blower that measures 19.7 x 15 mm and it doesn't quite fit. title: Modified Prusa I3 parts for a dedicated pen plotter / laser engraver. https://youtu.be/qLj5sCHtTaw

description.text:
Parts have been modified to use a T8 Lead Screw vs. a 5mm threaded rod. I had to move the T8 mounting holes about 3mm away from the 8mm smooth rod. The X carriage has been stripped of extruder and hot end parts and is now just a flat mounting plate for tools. The X carriage also has a mount for an 8mm inductive bed sensor. The pen holder assembly uses parts from a DVD drive. The pen holder rides on two 3mm smooth rods and no springs or rubber bands are required, just the weight of the pen and pen holder is enough to get a nice line. The clamps are sized for a fine point Sharpie. Use ABS or PETG for parts that hold stepper motors, otherwise PLA is OK.

GHere is where I found the Prusa parts that I modified: https://www.prusa3d.com/prusa-i3-printable-parts/

See it in action at https://youtu.be/qLj5sCHtTaw

title: Batarang The Dark Knight from Arkham Knights

description.text:
I made this Batarang in a couple of pieces for the ease of printing and painting. There are several variations in these files. In my pictures I used components 1 and 2 fillet along with 1.5 and 2.5 short so I could fill the center with resin. There are a few different ways to put this together so just pick on you like and have fun.

Way to print.
1x Batarang Body
1x Component 1 (can print fillet for rounded edge)
1x Component 1.5 (or print 1.5 short)
1x Component 2 (can print fillet for rounded edge)
1x Component 2.5 (or print 2.5 short)

The Body might need supports for the pointy edges.
All the 1.5 and 2.5 components will need support underneath so you have a flat top surface.
I probably will work on this at a later date to were if you glue Component 1 and 2 together it will spin in the middle.

Cookie cutters for cookie house. Also part holders to make assembling the cookie house easier.

For the house you need

6 triangular roofs

Please send photos of the cookie houses you've made.

remixed_from.title: Game of Thrones Longclaw Sword version 2

description.text:
Wallmount for Longclaw

Printed at 10% infill at .3mm layers.

These are Allen keys from M3 to M5. I created them by measuring the actual keys. I wanted to test some Polycarbonate and its strength. They came out a bit beefier. So in order for them to fit perfectly in the hole you have to melt the tip of it and press it inside the corresponding bolt.  
You can customize their dimensions in customizer too.  
They are pretty tough. I can't hold a nut with my hands and tight it more. When tightening an M5 bolt on the MendelMax it slipped and didn't break in half. Also it needed less than 1/4-turn tightening with the actual Allen key.  
I consider it working and may try it with the other thermoplastics too. Comes in handy to have those keys always on the machine.

INFO AND TUTORIAL ABOUT DISCO MODE ON MY TWITTER:
https://twitter.com/neotko/status/957423460942319617

Read the chain and enjoy

UPDATE JANUARY 11TH

Added BCNSIGMA1.27RCDUPLIMIRROR-EMVIO-E3D-and-BONDTECH.hex
For EMVIO E3D mod and Bondtech feeder esteps
Changes done on on the firmware
Line 280: #define TEMP_SENSOR_0 5
Line 281: #define TEMP_SENSOR_1 5
Line 806: #define INSERT_FAST_SPEED 2500 //max speed 60mm/s
As requested by a user on the Facebook BCN3D Groups
Also changed the Esteps for all the motherboard values except sigmax ofc to Bondtech recommended steps

UPDATE JANUARY 10TH
Updated with latest RC that seems to fix a SD card issue
https://github.com/BCN3D/BCN3DSigma-Firmware/tree/v01-1.2.7RC

UPDATE JANUARY 8TH
Rebuilded latest RC 1.27 from BCN github and changed the line that enables mirror/duplication for Sigma
https://github.com/BCN3D/BCN3DSigma-Firmware/tree/v01-1.2.7RC

Basic test that works on Twitter

Basic tutorial and printable Shims for BCN Sigma to use Mirror & Duplication mode

To enable Mirror and Duplication mode, for now it's necessary to change the firmware. Afaik BCN is already working on releasing this, but like everything it need to be tested.

Use the HEX and upload it using old bcn cura (they are also working on changing this, so don't worry much for now)

REMEMBER UPDATING THE FIRMWARE is AT YOUR OWN RISK. I did test it on my printer and works great, no issues, prints great, and most importantly it works.

Duplication & Mirror from BCNCura 1.03
When using on a Sigma, on BCNCura you need to

  • Create a new machine, and select SigmaX
  • Edit machine preferences to edit Max X
  • Change max X to half (so the print area is like a Sigma, not a sigmax)

Video example on my twitter
https://twitter.com/neotko/status/941737838172954624

Duplication from S3D

For S3D Mirror mode
Mirror mode - Change bed X to 77.5mm
ADD this to the end of the 'startgcode script'

M605 S6 ;mirror mode enabled
G4 P1
G4 P2
G4 P3

For S3D Duplication mode
Change X bed size to HALF
And add this to the end of the 'start gcode' script

M605 S5 ;duplication mode enabled
G4 P1
G4 P2
G4 P3

TO CALIBRATE BOTH HEADS at the same Z

Check this video. Basically you need to raise the one that's lower, to make them as close as possible to the same Z.

REMEMBER that you can on Cura use Raft Duplication/Mirror mode to avoid any recalibration of Z head (but I have not tested this since it's very easy to just raise one or the other to calibrate them)

ABOUT THE PRINTABLE SHIMS

PRINT AT 0.1 LAYER HEIGHT
ALSO IMPORTANT, CHANGE FIRST LAYER on CURA to also 0.1 height (hidden setting by default) and use HIGH Quality profile. I printed it on PLA and works great. For S3D set first layer height to 100% and use 0.1 Layer height

For any questions I answer MUCH faster on Twitter, if you leave a comment here spec slow speed on my answers.

http://www.twitter.com/neotko

author: 1-prop-head

description.text:
IMPORTANT:
This is a work in progress, updates to instructions and hints may follow.

This is a modification for the gerber dime keychain multitool. It gets rid of the build in flat head screw driver and flat phillips / file combo as well as (for now) the place for the tweezers.
In exchange you get a lockable 4mm precision bit driver plus space for a spare bit. So in theory and with two sided bits the trade is two bad drivers and a bad file for four proper drivers on the go.

Required tools:

  • 3D printer (duh)
  • gerber dime (also duh)
  • heat gun or blow torch
  • screw drivers for disassembly of the multitool
  • metal files

Required steps to prepare the time for the mod:
-> to be added later on!

Most parts are designed with a minimum wall thickness of 0.8mm. That way the printer can lay down the filament in a continuous line and form a stronger bond of the material.

After the print there are a couple of things to do before everything can be assembled to fit.
The hexagonal hole in the bitholder is most likely a bit undersized after the print and the top roof may have sagged a bit. To get a good fit for the precision bits i first heated up a metal nail with my blowtorch and melted the sagged roof a bit. After that i heated up a spare bit and slowly pushed it into the opening (giggedy). I also trimmed a couple millimeters off the end afterwards so my fingers can get a better grip on the bit when exchanging it.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2743585

I'm a big fan of the Warhammer 40k table top game. I've been looking around for a wheeled transport kit and wasn't able to find one. I decided to load up Sketchup and make one for myself.

The kit is designed in several pieces and is designed to be easily printed and assembled. You'll need two of the stacks and six of the wheels. You'll need one of everything else. I didn't think to take a picture, but you can look at the sides of the body and the "sides" to see that there are tabs and slots to help line up the pieces when gluing. The stacks glue onto the tops of the little side smoke stack exhaust pipes. The big hatch probably shouldn't be glued as I'm planning on uploading an upgrade kit that adds a couple of turret options.

If you're planning on painting, definitely paint the wheels before gluing them in place. It'll make your life much easier. Honestly, put some masking tape around the wheel pegs on the sides and there will probably be enough friction that you won't have to use glue.

If you like this, comment! If you make one, post it! Positive feedback energizes me to make more stuff.

title: Crutch Tip Rubber Foot Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a printable adapter part to help repair and beef-up the rubber "foot" (or tip) on a typical set of crutches.

Not sure why manufacturers of crutches want their product to end up in a landfill because something so simple breaks so easily, but this is meant to help defeat that planned "disposability." I would also like for this to counteract a tiny bit of the obnoxious, wasteful, bordering-on-insurance-fraud, needless consumption that starts with a healthcare provider asking "Why don't you just get a new set of crutches? Your insurance pays for most of it anyway."

The included stl file is sized for the crutches we got last time someone twisted or sprained something and fits a Home Depot, "Everbilt" brand Rubber Leg Tip - 1 1/4" size. (SKU 827121). The fender washers that fit on the bottom of the printed part, inside the Rubber Leg Tip, should make it close to impossible for the crutch post to punch through the bottom. The washers can also be found at Home Depot: outside diameter 1 1/4" & inside diameter 3/16".

Including the OpenSCAD source file in case you want to tweak the dimensions to fit your, possibly slightly different, set of crutches.

A Minecraft (tm) torch with wall mount and decals, for flashlights or other, custom light sources.

You expect your children to help in the household?
Print this - problem solved.
Promised ;-)

Short assembly/parts video:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WBvu3jul6pA

Do NOT print the included STL files.
These are only examples to clarify the "printing number" in the OpenSCAD source file.
This file also contains a lot of explanations and (hopefully) other helpful notes.

You'll need a flashlight with a rear button. Preferably, the top lens
can be detached.
By default, the torch has the dimensions (40 x 40 x 200)mm.
Any flashlight up to a length of ~140mm and a diameter < ~34mm can be used.
If it does not fit, the torch's size needs to be increased.
Keep in mind that this also requires scaling the the print-sheet, with
the Minecraft torch decals on it.

The flashlight edition of the Minecraft Torch consists of:
  • bottom part (handle; the torch itself)
  • top part (the "flame")
  • fixture ring, to hold the flashlight in place
  • pusher, fits inside fixture ring and pushes the flashlight power botton
    For the "power cord edition", please see the notes in the OpenSCAD source file.
  • unpack "Screw_Library.zip" to the same path as the OpenSCAD file
  • open the OpenSCAD file in an editor (or the OpenSCAD IDE)
  • scroll down and find the line
    PRINTPART = 22; // choose which part to print
    This is where you specify which of the parts should be printed.
    Each of them is listed in a table, right above this line and most
    of the parts are included in the download section.
  • the table above the print part selection line clearly shows what the selected part can be used for:
    PRINT -> printing export of final parts
    TEST-PRINT -> printing export of reduced test prints
    EDIT -> for tuning/viewing/editing inside OpenSCAD
    SHOW -> shows an overview of what you designed
    The three test parts 10, 11 and 12 are shown in the image:
    top left: where the flashlight's head should fit in
    top right: thread of the "bottom part" (the torch itself)
    bottom: the thread of the fixture ring
    Print these to make sure that the head of the flashlights and the threads fit. The small prints save a lot of time and material.
  • begin to modify it ;-)
    Yes, it definitely will take some time, but I am sure you'll get the clue.
    The OpenSCAD source file also contains an ASCII drawing which might help identifying the parameters and what geometry they change.
    ...

    NOTES FOR PRINTING:

    • BOTTOM PART:
      Print top-down, like already prepared in the STL output (print mode).
    • TOP PART:
      Needs to be printed in "vase mode", with no infill and open top.
      Usually one perimeter line is all you need.
      Keep an eye on "tTopCut", which determines how much material is cut off the bottom part
      to make the top part slide on it.
    • FIXTURE RING:
      It should not be required to add support structures.
      The overhanging thread will print nice if you slow down the machine a little (30..50mm/s)
      and keep the layer height <=0.2mm.
      I set infill to 33%.

      The wall mount has a slot and a hole at the bottom so that a Minecraft torch can be put in or taken out while a cable is attached to it.
      ...

UPDATE 9/2014:
I included the missing screw library, which can also be found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8793

title: Lighting Christmas Tree RGB LED - auto change color - button cell - DIY

description.text:
This is a DIY project, which you can create pretty easily. The result is a Christmas tree which changes it's color automatically, looking really cool and making a good mood in your home.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qkzKGrSLb4A

You will need:

  • the attached 3D models printed out (the placeholder can be printed out simply with normal settings, but the Christmas tree should be printed out in vase mode - https://goo.gl/YAvigH)
  • a 5mm Cycling RGB LED (https://goo.gl/gdDYvB)
  • one cr3032 coin cell - 3V battery
  • one cr3032 plastic battery holder (https://goo.gl/qMrqX4)
  • hot glue or any other glue
  • some hand tools and solder
  • basic crafting skills

You have to solder the positive side of the battery holder to the LED anode and the negative side to the cathode (shown on the pictures). You have to place the battery into the battery holder. You can use the little piece of plastic placeholder as a switch, just simply pressing it between the battery and the connector, so it interrupts the circuit. You need some hot glue to glue the whole thing in to the Christmas tree.

If you have any questions, you can ask me. Have fun!

Printer:

CraftBot PLUS

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20% at placeholder, 0% at the tree

Notes:

The placeholder can be printed out simply with normal settings, but the Christmas tree should be printed out in vase mode - https://goo.gl/YAvigH

description.text:
No more accidentally shorting out your bed when leveling it by dropping the Allen key on the heated bed contacts. While you can cover the contacts of the heated bed pcb with blue bed tape to protect them here is a more permanent solution.

This is a protective cover for the heated bed connection on a Rigidbot 2 (RB2) or a ReliaBuild 3D (RB3, RBB3) printer. Any Rigidbot that uses the upgraded 4E3D heated bed pcb can use this protective cover as well.

It pops on over the connection area around the locking cable socket and keeps things out from the top and the side. It has performed well for me in many hours of printing without warping or falling off.

The file is oriented for printing and scaled in Cura. Use thermally calibrated filament for best fit results. The clips found here work really well for calibration. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1037301

Printer:

Rigidbot 2 (RB2)

title: Galaxy Note 8 Car Phone Holder (CD Slot!)

description.text:
This is designed to work with a slim-style case installed on the phone, but will also work without any kind of case. Unless you live somewhere cold year-round, print this in a high-heat resistant filament unless you want it to melt in the sun. You can access the charging port, the power button, and all volume buttons. Phone is placed in the holder horizontally with the top of the phone to the right. the holder should slide into the CD slot. The holding area itself is slightly canted back. I printed mine with #MakerGeeks Natural Raptor PLA, which can be annealed in the oven and remain strong up to 200F.

**MAKE SURE YOU MEASURE THE AREA AROUND YOUR CD SLOT!!! I made this to fit the CD slot in my 2016 Ford Fusion, so the insert for the slot is high on the model, which means the phone sits rather low. I did this to put the phone out of the way of the touchscreen. Check to make sure this will clear your knobs and such.

I just received a Geeetech i3 printer and as I am going to make some modifications, I will put here what I come up with. First modification is to change the carriage X axis from vertical to horizontal (something like Anet A6). For this, I redesign the Z axis plates and the X carriage. The interaxis of the bearing will be 60mm as the actual structure limits that.
The hot end will be an E3D V6 and there will be a direct drive extruder.
The belt tensioner pulley and U plate are the Geeetech ones, just the screw has to be cut a little bit shorter, just to fit the nut.
The extruder lever's spring is just the same used for the bed levelling.
The bearing for the extruder lever is 5x5x16mm. (I am probably going to modify this to use the original toothed pulley and bearing from original Geeetech extruder the next time I will take it apart so I can take measures).
The linear bearings for the X carriage are the ones from the original extruder X carriage.

title: Dremel Guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a snap on guide for the Dremel 565 Multi-Purpose Cutting Kit. I designed this for use with plastic cutting/ trimming jigs. The collar at the bottom of the part allows you to follow the outside of your jig without the rotation of the bit melting the jig.(keep in mind that you need to account for the offset between the bit and the OD of the collar.)

Offset with standard 1/8" trim bits: 0.1375"
collar OD = 0.4"
collar height = 0.25"

It can be installed by pressing it on, but it can be tricky. It's much easier to install and remove by removing the center of the Dremel guide and using a pair of channel locks to compress the tongs.

description.text:
Root 3 LITE!

Official Website!

Join our forum and ask questions with our community.
https://www.rootcnc.com

Info

Current Version = R3_LITE_1

The Root 3 Lite is base from the R3 standard version but one a smaller desktop size footprint. R3 Lite uses 20mm box section instead of the 25mm box sections used on the Root 3 and Root 2 machines. It is aim toward the light works loads than the its bigger brother but dont let the small size fool you - this machine is very capable.

Key design decisions:
1- use only NEMA 17 stepper motors - I wanted to try and keep this machine fairly standard to easy new comers to the CNC arena.
2- Use standard 3d Printer parts
3- lighter weight Carriages - I would like to try and turn this into a 3D printer in the future.

Build one

Please if you build one, post some photos! I would love to see them!

Shop

If you need parts for your CNC Machine then visit the Root CNC shop
https://rootcnc.com/shop/

Facebook

Consider joining us on our Facebook group to share and ask questions.
https://www.facebook.com/groups/1023078667749894/

Forum

https://rootcnc.com/forums/

YouTube

Check out my YouTube Chanel
https://www.youtube.com/user/sailorpete12

If you like the work I have been doing and fancy supporting me, please feel free to hit the “Tip Designer” button up top. It’s much appreciated

This design is meant to replace the X-Axis and Y-Axis bearing and pillow blocks on my ANET-A8. I'm also using it on the X-Axis of my RepRap-8 (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2562389).

The design includes both the the bearing and the pillow block. Features include:

  • Adjustable tension
  • Easily replace worn FDM printed bearing without the need of a complete axis disassembly.
  • Drop in alternative for existing bearings/blocks.
  • Can work for both X and Y axis (X-belt allowances have been made).
  • Printed bearings optional, pillow blocks can be used with existing LM8UU or INGUS bearings.
  • Easily try out new and exotic filaments as bearings.

The assembly only requires a single 3mm screw, 3mm lock-nut, a small length of 1.75mm filament and four 4mm nuts. The screw is used for both tension adjustment and for securing the upper and lower halves of the pillow block. The filament is used as the barrel for the hinge.

The best feature of this design is the ease of replacement. For the X-Axis which means your 3 screws away from an exchangeable X carriage.

BTW: The photo with the pile of these bearings are the failure created during development :-p.

Cheers,
-HD

Printer:

ANET-A8 / REPRAP-8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.28

Infill:

20%

The depth of the 4mm holes used to mount the block are 9mm deep. If you only need to use the standard m4x8 screws, nothing needs to be done. Otherwise, you can use a 4mm drill bit to break through the skin at the top of the nut housing to allow another 3mm of depth.

Insert a 3mm lock nut using a pair of pliers and press fit.

Attach the block's base to the top by assembling the hinge. The hinge uses a small lenth of 1.75mm filament for its barrel. The holes will most likely require reaming using a 2mm drill bit. Once inserted, use a soldering iron to melt the ends. I use an 'X' pattern (see photo).

When installing, make sure the bearing tabs are against the top of the block. There is a channel cut into the top part that they should fit snugly inside.

I've designed the block to work with a +/- 2% over/under extrusion rate. On the extreme under-extrusion, a strip of masking tape (~0.2mm thick) can be added to the base block and the back of the printed bearing opposite the screw. Or of course, you could just oversize the printed bearings.

If you print these out, let me know how they hold up over time. You'll most likely have to adjust the tension after a week or so to account for the initial wear and material shrinkage.

3/8/2018
Uploaded new pictures for complete build of 13 GPU (RX470 mining edition) mining rig using 2 frames.

1/28/2018
We use the following vitamins to build:

Screw M3 5mm 1-2 per GPU for top mount - 6-12 pcs
Screw M3 8mm for rest of build (including Riser boards)- 80 pcs
Nut M3- 100 pcs
Washers M3 Used only for 3-Way corners and Power supply mount- 19 pcs

Kit available for sale now.

New future is: You can easy stack frames.
You can start with 7 GPU then easy upgrade it to 13-14 GPU by stock under second frame

description.text:
This is Tak: a beautiful game.

Those who have read kingkiller chronicles will recognize this game. Those who have not definitely should!

The description of this game in the book drew the attention of many board game enthusiasts and lead to the creation of the game with the help of the author.

I can't claim much on the design here. I combined 2 different tak games from others to create a full set of board and pieces. I also combined a two piece board into a single piece board for those of us with larger printers and the borrowed a board game base from an entirely different game to allow everything to be stored in a single convenient box. All I did was adjust scaling and size on all the various pieces so they match up to make a complete game that fits together well.

You can find the game rules here: http://cheapass.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/TakWebRules.pdf

I have also included a QR code that I attach to the bottom of the games I print - pointing your phone's camera towards it will bring up a link to go to the game rules making it easy to give your friends the game rules when you play.

I hope you enjoy the game!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Infill:

18%

Notes:

You'll want to use an infill in the area of 50% for the pieces to give them a bit of heft...otherwise this is a very easy print.

description.text: Spiral christmas tree

Find attached Assembled STL file. For individual plates see Reference files by Makerblock .   
Not intended for printing, just proof that the pieces do in fact fit together.  You can use this file to try out different colors before printing and have a little fun with it.  
This isn't a remix as such, I just took the time to assemble the spider in 3D digital, and believe me, it was an exercise in patience as I didn't have a physical model to go by, only pictures of previous builds.  
This Spider does fit together, even though its a little tight ... I'm not even going to glue this one together, its friction fit all the way !  
Ignore the overlap abdomen in this model, it was getting late and I placed one in the wrong place. If you assemble the abdomen pieces Largest to Smallest with the largest piece closest to the head it WILL work in the real world .....

comments.text:
That would be a very difficult thing to put into text format ! the easiest answer is to look at the pictures, place the longest legs at the back, arrange abdomen parts large to small starting from the front and put the face plate in LAST.
It was a very very tight fit to get the face plate in, but ounce its in there is likely no getting it back out ! I had to use a little sandpaper for the really tight joints.
The different colors of plastic had different degrees of shrinkage (red being the worst). Printing large like I did might make life a little easier, but I want to try some smaller versions some day.

title: Anet A8 Z-axis anti-wobble top plates for 608Z bearings

description.text: I was looking for a set of z-axis anti-wobble top plates for my printer (Anet A8) that wouldn't be too "weird". I couldn't find it so I decided to make my own.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20-30%

I used the original top plates' design (based on the full acrylic frame design files found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2288314) and modified them to bring in 608Z bearings.Holes for the bearings are recessed 7mm down from the top of the plates leaving 1mm lip for proper seating. There is a 0.5mm chamfer on the bearing holes for ease of driving them in. There are also 0.5mm fillets on the bottom of the cutouts for the rest of the frame for the ease of mounting.

comments.text: My biggest concern was that no matter what, the stock setup makes the Z axis lead screws wobble in their holes. Thus, making it very sensitive to any shifts. Try it out - even with stiffen rods, just wiggle your lead screw a little bit and observe the carriage - it will shift slightly. If not - please share some tips and tricks on how to prevent that behavior without my little fix. Take a look at this Benchy.

description.text:
The stock spool holder on the JGAurora A3S holds my filament spools too low and they drag on the wires of the machine. This spool holder attaches to the stock mounting plates and raises the spool holder up by several mm.

I'm pleased with the print, and it fits all of my spools. I updated the original with a little extra added chamfer to the bend at the arm to the mount plate to add just a bit more strength.

Let me know if your spool is too wide and you need a slghtly longer spool holder cylinder.

The tolerance on the cap is a bit loose as it came off my printer, as there is .5mm by design. Hopefully that's enough to allow for some variation in printer settings to still print successfully.

Printer:

JGAurora A3S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

2mm shell because the spool holder shaft will take the weight of a 1kg spool.

On the A3S, this took 11.5 hours to print.

Make sure that you print the cap with the indentation up so that it will print cleanly.

You'll need to glue the pieces together with super glue.

You'll also need some longer 3mm screws because the new holder is 5mm thick. Three 8-10mm M3 screws should work.
Designed in Fusion 360 based upon direct measurements of original spool holder.

comments.text: If you want to truely test the accuracy of your printer then go ahead. 1st attempt - completely fused. Calibrated the extruder and found it was pushing 6mm too much over 100mm! 2nd attempt noticed my rounds were ovals, calibrated the steps/mm and Y OK but X was out by 0.37! 3rd attempt issues with bed levelling, finally bit the bullet and installed the auto bed sensor thats been stilling on my desk for the last 6 months and change my stock firmware to Marlin (ANET A8 Printer). A week of mucking around and testing and finally 4th Attempt it worked. Never thought a crappy AU$200 printer would ever do it but there you go it actually will do it with correctly setting EVERYTHING!

comments.author: DinoMC

comments.text:
Hi
First of all, these has been designed to be printed without a raft, so remove that option. shells are how many outlines the model gets (walls), I recommend 3 shells since that will make the wheel axles stronger. Do not auto-repair, not sure what that does but it might weld parts together that should not be welded together. If the hinges are fused together it often means that the printer is extruding a bit too much filament, and that is often fixed by lowering the feed rate (In the Simplify3D slicer that setting is called Extrusion Multiplier, not sure what it is called in your slicer if you are not using S3D). I also see some strange layer steps on the printed part in your photo, not sure what causes that, you might need to lower the printer speed to increase precision
I hope this helps, and please let me know how it goes if you do some more tests
Best regards
Stian
comments.author: DinoMC

comments.text: I have the exact same issue. Did you find a solution?
comments.author: endrw

comments.text:
turn the model 180 or 90 degrees from where you are now and try again the MK2 cannot cool the backside of a shape very well.
turning the model has an effect on cooling and how the layers go down and can help.
comments.author: endrw

comments.text: Looking at you photos it also looks like you are overextruding. Try lowering the feedrate. Some of the curling might be because of the excess materials
comments.author: endrw

comments.text: Print Slower and at a lower temperature and with fan at 100%

description.text: A simple but effective mount for attaching a BLTouch to the head of your Wanhao Duplicator i3 (or Monoprice Maker Select, Cocoon Create, etc). Screws onto the fan mount, and can be used in conjunction with a front-mounted fan shroud, as long as your screws are long enough.

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Notes:

Use a stiff material for maximum performance. I used carbon fiber PETG, but a stiff PLA, or possibly even ABS, could work too.

Linear stage for 20 mm motor from aliexpress with 28 mm mount base that is on the same line as axis. Lead-screw is ACME 3 mm diameter, also from aliexpress. I found that this motor is somewhat weak, so you may want to try other options or lead-screws with smaller step.

Parametric FreeCAD model is attached to match device to your needs.

Parameters that can be adjusted from a spreadsheet:
1) Diameter of the rails
2) Fudge factor to match your printer
3) Motor mount base
4) Motor axis offset
n) Many more

To change lead-screw you need to import or design a proper one and do cut from pusher block.

I was able to print all threads precise enough, so that no taps was needed.

As of material, PLA has too high friction against steel rods, so ABS might be better. Nylon is the best, but it is hard to glue parts together.

description.text:
My daughter wanted a portal gun for Dragon Con but you couldn't buy them yet. So I went ahead and designed one for both of us. I incorporated LEDs into the gun and some minor electronics to make it cool looking. The Counsel of Ricks Badge was not my design.

I am posting the answer to two questions here as well and adding a picture to help explain.

I used magnets in the tubes that I designed into the bottom box portion and thin metal squares were melted into the lid to create a secure "closing" of the gun. It works very well.
Also shown in this new picture is the wiring as it is and the battery compartment I 3D printed. (Props go to the designer of the battery holder, nice job.) You have to add metal contacts to it, but it works very well. I used gaffer's tape to keep light from the LEDs from going everywhere as well as some metal tape. They are very bright LEDs. I used a bubble magic wand for my green fusion container instead of printing it. Bought a goo spike ball, cut it in half and wrapped it around some LEDs before putting it in the green container.

As with all my items, it is not required, but a tip through Paypal is always appreciated for my work. Thanks and Enjoy!
This is a picture of all the parts. I used a Bubble Magic wand for the green portion.

comments.text: I put a pressure switch in under the button in the handle, printed a battery box for 3 batteries and put LEDs in the green bubble and in the green bulbs in front. comments.text: How did you wire the leds?
comments.author: Nickfd24

comments.text: So, I added a picture and some description to help.  When it came to wiring the LEDs, I just put them in series.  So one wire starts at the battery and goes to a resistor and daisy chains to each LED and then to the switch.  From the other side of the switch, it goes to the other end of the battery.  The resistor size depends on the LEDs you use.  There are many LED calculators on line that can figure out that for you.

title: Grip Shifter for Rohloff
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Early draft

Warning: not yet tested. At all. Probably doesn't work yet.

This is a shifter for a Rohloff SpeedHub 500/14. Or it's supposed to be, and will be one day. For now, it's very much a work in progress.

The Rohloff SpeedHub is a 14-speed internally-geared rear hub for a bicycle. It ships with a very nice shifter, but that shifter only fits straight bars (22.2mm diameter bars). There are solutions for road bars (23.8mm), but most seem unsatisfying, and/or are rather expensive.

One of the great features of the Rohloff SpeedHub is that it is indexed internally, inside the hub. So the shifter itself is a simple pulley mechanism, rigged so the cables turn a wheel near the hub.

This design is executed in OpenSCAD, and is fully parametric, so you can scale it to any bar size you like, as well as adjusting other parameters.

I speculate that this will ultimately work best in Nylon (lower friction), but PETG, ABS or ASA might work well too.

Installation

Still working on this too...

Additional materials

  1. 1 M4 nut
  2. 1 M4x8 bolt.

Directions

  1. Clean the supports off the stator and out of the ferrule ports.
  2. Slip the nut into the nut slot on the stator.
  3. Thread the bolt into the nut, so the hex head is on the outside.
  4. Stick the hexagonal clamp into the hole inside the stator, so that it's flush with the stator wall.
  5. Slide the stator onto the handlebar (does it successfully navigate drop bar curves?).
  6. Screw down the bolt, so that it compresses the hexagonal clamp, clamping it to the bar.
  7. Slide on the rotor. (It just kind of sits there right now; need a retention mechanism)
  8. Install cables (TODO: details)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Supports for now, for the cable sockets on the stator, and the awkward bridge with a hole in the ferrule sockets.

Optimized for 0.4mm walls, but the "line" param can be used to customize that. Seems to test-print well at 0.2mm layer height.

Infill should be considerable, but I'm not yet sure on the needs. I'm printing test pieces at 10% or so; 50% seems reasonable for production, but it's hard to say. At low infill, the internal cap surface of the stator prints poorly, as it needs to just float there for a while.

At 10%, it's about 70g of PLA. At high speed and 0.2mm layer height, it takes around 4 hours to print.

Material is another variable I'm uncertain on. I'll print fit-tests in PLA most likely, because I feel less bad about discarding it, but final parts should probably be Nylon (it's low-friction), PETG, ABS or ASA (good if your bike is sitting in the sun all the time).

description.text:
Thirty miles outside of New York City, nestled in the Long Island town of Amityville, stands the house forever linked to the Amityville Horror phenomenon. On November 13, 1974 the estate was the scene of a mass murder. Using a .35 Marlin rifle, 23-year-old Ronald J. DeFeo Jr. murdered his entire family while they were asleep, which included his parents and four siblings.

Thirteen months later, the Lutz Family purchased the 5-bedroom, 3.5 bathroom home at a drastically reduced price of $80,000 (due to the murders) but only lasted 28 days before leaving it. Their spine-tingling tales of paranormal activity is what propelled the legend of the Amityville Horror, "America's most haunted house

Boomphones feel well built but unfortunately like any good headphones they have their weak spots and do break. Replacement parts don't exist and glue wont stick it. The part that breaks on these are the 1.5mm wall on the tube connecting the head band to its speaker. This replacement part isn't a direct replica of the original but a quick and dirty modified version “to allow the cable to be placed rather than having to de-solder / resolder and thread through” (yes, its lazy and makes them weaker but its convenient) the throat wall has been thickened to compensate and the twist stop on this throat has been widened and reinforced with a metal pin (you can use a small nail or wire) . I printed mine in PLA it seems ok. My aim was to quickly repair these for a friend so you may need to fillet the edges in CAD but I like to use sand paper. I created this part in FreeCAD and include the STL and original file so it should be easy to modify / improve as you like.

description.text:
I wanted a new spool holder for my i3 MK2 that was easy and quick to load, and held the spools from the center hub area to reduce rolling resistance. After a bit of trial and error this is what I came up with.

It requires four 608 skater bearings pressed into the hub, four 5/16" nuts, and a 5/16" threaded rod. I started with a 1ft rod from the hardware store and eventually cut it down to size. That isn't required. The handle is threaded internally and should thread onto the shaft.

Print 2 center hubs, 2 uprights and a handle. I used 0.2mm layer height for everything. The bearing stop on the flanged side of the hub is tapered, so it shouldn't require any support.

Check out more pictures and details of my design on my blog:
http://kiltedcraftworks.com/2017/12/16/prusa-spool-upgrade

This is a solution to a problem I bet nobody else has, yet I'm posting it here anyway. Basically, I still have a Zune. I still like to charge my Zune. My charging cable is so old that one of the little release buttons literally fell off. I've had to find something long and thin to push that spot in, every time I want to release my Zune from its charger. So, I made a little doohickey that will wrap around the part with the buttons, and has little rods that will push each button-hole in. It wraps around the existing button just fine, too.

And it has the Zune logo on it, because why not.

This is a model of a frost dragon taken from the game Skyrim. It is not my original creation.

The original model was altered to shorten the rock it stands on, close the holes, and create thicker wings. At full size assembled, it is approximately 37 cm wide x 32 cm high x 40 cm deep. The parts at full scale fit on an Original Prusa MK2S.

I have included the dragon all in one piece (frost dragon.stl) in case you want to scale it down and not bother with assembling pieces.

I have hollowed the parts to save material and at full scale they have 1mm thick walls, except for the bottom-most (pillar bottom) piece to give it more weight. You may wish to add even more weight as the statue's center of gravity is shifted to the front and may tip on unstable surfaces.

Sorry there's no pics of the parts by themselves, I was assembling and painting as I went along.

description.text:
Do you want to plant small flowers and water it automatically ?.

Version-0 : 17-Dec-17
This is the base container I designed as first serious design towards greener homes. Use a solid wooden wedge strip to fix this container and make an array of it.

I have provided a watering draft in form of small 4mm tubular section followed by a through and through recess. This recess is kept slightly above the lower edge of pot so that it wan't get choked due to soil. The 4mm circular section slightly extend below the recess and will act as anti splashing. Keep the flow rate of water very low.

Version-1 17-Dec-17
Upper dovetail 'curtailed' and bottom dovetail removed. Instead of bottom dovetail, supports are provided for serving overall purpose. Thanks for inputs from DropCat.

Update : 22 - Dec-17
Refer below https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2238218 link for Hygormeter based water system. Or look at (Thanks to Enzi1984)

4 relay module, 5V:
https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B01M8G4Y7Z/

module YL-38 for Hygrometer:
https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00ZR3B60I/

D-Sub, 25-pin:
https://www.conrad.at/de/d-sub-buchsenleiste-180-polzahl-25-loetkelch-1-st-741698.html

Additionally, you have to go for an arduino/R-Pi and hygrometer along with a pump and motor for automatic watering. To make this fully autonomous and ecofriendly, you may operate the electronis/electric motor on Solar cell.

Let me know if you make one and contribute towards 'Greener home'

I bought my son an inexpensive 2002 Audi Quattro for hopping between locations while he goes through Apprentice University. We do get occasional ice storms, so this seemed like a good idea. I also have a couple VW TDIs, so I already have the Ross-Tech VCDS that can work with the ECU and other electronics in this car.

When we bought the car it came with only one key, and I quickly found out that the VCDS would help me to program remotes, but it wouldn't help me with the RFIDs in the immobilizers. I didn't want to spend an arm or a leg on keys for a cheap car, so I hunted for another option. I found that I could get a couple simple metal keys cut for cheap, but there had to be a way around the immobilizer.

Well, I realized that if the RFID was kept at the ignition switch, it would always be visible and any properly-shaped key could start the car. So, I built this to hold the RFID in place.

Yes, this compromises the car's security, but I've had much more valuable things in my life protected by less-secure physical keys and locks that could be picked more easily than this Audi's.

After doing this, I've actually printed a key from Jason555's Audi Key model https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1844427 and actually used it to start the car!

author: balassy

print_settings.Notes:: You will need 2 prints for all files, except the last one (FruitBowlV2_05). Only need one print of the last.

title: Fruit Bowl
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix of the Fruit Bowl by @ImaginationCreation3D which is itself a derivative of Fruit Bowl "Sphere" cnc/laser by @ZenziWerken. Thanks for the great work people!

I had to split up the parts to be able to fit the tiny 1203 mm3 build platform on my MP Select Mini v2.

You will need 2 prints for all files, except the last one (FruitBowlV2_05). Only need one print of the last.

Assembly should be fairly intuitive, but if you need a step-by-step, here it is:

  1. See the Post-Printing section to join the parts that come in split pieces
  2. Start with placing part #05 in the middle with the flat-side down
  3. Place the #04 parts parallel on either side of that
  4. Place the #03 parts above this arrangement crossing it
  5. Then the #02 and #01 parts cross the #03 on the outer side of the bowl to finish it up.

You'll notice I had to tie the joints with thread to make sure the bowl holds together. If I print another one some time, I'll probably make the parts clip onto each other with pin connectors. If someone else wants to remix this design to do that before I get around to it, be my guest!

Printer:

MP Select Mini v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Layer height: 0.2, Shell thickness: 1.2

Infill:

15

Notes:

You will need 2 prints for all files, except the last one (FruitBowlV2_05). Only need one print of the last.

Connecting the ermm.. connectors

You may need to sand the male end of the connectors slightly to be able to pass it into the female end. I've designed the connectors to not come off if pulled apart, as a result you can only insert the connectors laterally (sideways), won't work if you push length-wise.

Don't sand too much, or you won't get a sturdy grip when you put it together.

Before After: You will have to press down the pieces from the top, not press together length-wise.

comments.text: Didn't think I could make this with my mini printer. Thanks for showing me I can!

title: Prusa Comfort Grip Handle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I am a mobile college student, and my 3D printer is something that travels often. Personally, I found that carrying the Prusa by its frame was relatively uncomfortable, so I solved the issue by designing this super-simple comfort grip that friction slides onto the frame, so it can be comfortably carried. I intend on improving upon this design later on, but if you guys want to edit it and share it, that would be awesome!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

50 microns

Infill:

20%+

Notes:

I printed this in eSun ABS+. Infill percentage does not really matter, as long as it is higher than 20%. I printed this at 50 microns so the edges would be smooth and more comfortable.

Rotate the object 90 degrees about the Y, so it is standing up with the hand grips perpendicular to the bed. I used a brim of 3mm to increase overall surface area. This is highly recommended as it will not adhere otherwise.

author: CircuitConnections

title: dc42 Mini Differential IR height sensing board to Prusa i3 MK2 Multimaterial adapter plate

description.text:
This little adapter plate allows you to attach a dc42 Mini Differential IR height sensing board to your Prusa i3 MK2 Multimaterial printer. (I think it should also work for Prusa i3 MK2s.)

Update: v2 includes cutouts for capacitor thru-holes.
Update: v3 includes threaded screw-holes.

The dc42 sensor board seems to be electrically a drop-in replacement for the MK2 PINDA probe from Prusa. I didn't have to make any changes to my firmware to start using this probe for z-height sensing.

You will leave your existing PINDA probe in place because the IR sensor cannot be used to do full XYZ calibration; the dc42 can only be used to do Mesh Bed Leveling, but it is not effected by temperature like the PINDA.

To get started, print this adapter board then power off and unplug your printer.

Next, prepare your dc42 board. My dc42 came with 24" Red, Orange, and Yellow wiring harness, and with headers pre-installed; I had to bend the headers on the board up, at 90º angle, to be able to fit the board into the hot-end.

Disassemble the plastic headers from one end of the dc42 wiring harness. Slide a short length of heat-shrink tubing onto each wire, then directly solder the VCC (Red), Ground (Orange), and Signal (Yellow) wires to the proper header pins on the sensor board. Slide down the heat-shrink tubing and shrink it to seal the wires.

Screw the dc42 sensor board directly to the adapter plate, using two short M3 screws. I used an M3 threaded-tap to tap the holes in the dc42 board, and two M3 x 8mm hex-head screws.

Next, the hardest part: you will use cyanoacrylate super-glue to glue the adapter board to the back side of your PINDA probe mounting bracket. See the picture for placement.

I applied a small amount of glue to the back of the adapter plate and carefully lined up the bottom of the dc42 sensing board so it is the recommended 1.5 mm above the tip of the hot-end nozzle.

I lined up the bottom of the dc42 board just even with the bottom of the PINDA probe and this distance seems to work great. Then press into place and hold for 20-30 seconds

Next, open your Mini-Rambo case and un-plug your existing PINDA probe from the Mini Rambo, but leave the PINDA probe itself in place on the hot end. Leave the PINDA connector unconnected, and tuck it inside the MiniRambo case.

Route the new wires from the sensor between the 8mm Y-axis rods, and into the existing wiring harness, and plug it into the same spot on your Rambo Mini board where you unplugged the PINDA.

That's it! Close everything up and re-do your Z-calibration from the LCD menu.

Print a test print, and as soon as it start printing, you will need to do "Live Adjust Z"; I had to add a full 2 mm to my Live Adjust Z setting.

comments.text: This is a really cool Idea. WHat is the purpose of gluing the PCB to the pinda probe?

author: nanosmith

title: ToolTote
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
** ToolTote

The ToolTote is designed to have a complete set of tools, for around the house use, in the smallest space possible. Tools are positioned with the working end up so it is easy to find the tool you need.

Screwdrivers is designed to hold these common Craftsman Screwdrivers:

Slotted:
3/32 x 1 1/2 #41541
1/8 x 4 #41589
3/16 x 4 #41581

Phillips:
P0 x 1 1/2 #41542
P1 x 3 #41294
P2 x 4 #41295

An extra hole is provided for a larger driver (Point Down) and a wall to hold a small measuring tape.

Pliers is designed to hold 5 Pliers, should fit most Plier Sets handles

Drill-Driver is designed for a Bosch 12v Drill-Driver. Most Drill-Drivers with a 1/4" Hex drive extention should work. It has holders for extra 1/4" Hex bits, drills and extentions.

Parts Holder is designed with a cup to put loose screws in, a drawer for holding some extra screws, a place for a torpedo level, a small flashlight and 2 Pencil holes.

T Handle has a hole for a pencil, marker and small utility knife. If you need a hammer, carry it in your hand while holding the handle.

Blocks and Handle were designed for a small print bed or you can combine all the parts into one model and print the whole thing as one piece. If the blocks printed seperately, you can glue them together or better yet, drill throught the back of each Block (throught Handle) and bolt together. Wells have been included in Drill-Driver Block to allow room to fit nuts on the end of bolts.

CAUTION: Since all the tools are point up, be careful not fall on ToolTote or you will be stuck with all your tools.

author: METdev

description.text:
This is a Toronto Blue Jays hanging ornament made specifically for multi-extruder printers (though I have included a one-piece model for single-extruder machines). It's perfect for the rear-view mirror, Christmas tree, etc.

Please be aware that the colourized version of this model was not designed to be printed in pieces on a single-extruder machine and assembled afterwards. Use bluejays_onepiece.stl to get everything at once in a single colour.

The print in the cover photo was done on a quad extruder Prusa i3 MK2 MMU as follows:

  • bluejays_white.stl white PLA (extruder 1)
  • bluejays_blue.stl blue PLA (extruder 2)
  • bluejays_red.stl red PLA (extruder 3)

In addition to the .stl files used in my print, I have included the following:

  • bluejays_onepiece.stl: This can be used to print everything at once in a single colour/material.

When printed at 100% size, the ornament measures 100mm in diameter. I scaled my print down to 75% to get a size that worked for me.

Happy printing!

title: Foam board 90 degree cutter with depth control
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to have a tool which ensures that my foam board cuts are perpendicular, and allows me to perfectly control the depth of the cut. So I designed this model that hosts a hobby knife modeling (carving) blade, that can be fully retracted for storage.

You can use M2 screws to mount the blade, though I've found it better to slightly enlarge the hole on the blade with my Dremel, and use M3 screws. Then you can apply an M3 knob (tip: there are tons of them here on Thigiverse) on the back, so you can adjust the depth of the cut without any other tool.

description.text: I could not find a case for the moto x4 on thingiverse to protect my screen so I learned how to model a phone case using videos on YouTube. I chose to make it out of PLA because from my experience, ABS will warp when printing something this size. I would like to see any other moto x4 cases that anybody would model.

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.1mm

100%

Notes:

I would recommend cutting away all material above the volume and power button slots. It makes it easier to get the phone in. It is a tight fit. The phone move maybe a half a millimeter when you shake the case. Feel free to scale it if you are willing to experiment.
Trim away material above power and volume slots to make it easier to fit the phone in. I would recommend rounding off the corners with a file.

I began by modeling the rough shape of the phone by placing pictures of the phone to scale, tracing the edges and extruding all in fusion 360. The case was not the best fit and I just wanted to scale the y and x axis at different multipliers but I could not figure out how to do that in fusion 360 so I uploaded the stl file to tinkercad and scaled the model that way. This is the third iteration of this case. This is also the first phone case that I have designed.
