title: Fallout Board Game Orgainzer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a Fallout Board Game organizer. The insert & bags that the original game comes with are woefully inadequate, so, I made my own.

Since I don't have a printer that prints at 11.5" by 11.5", I had to piece meal it together. Each section has it's own tray with the exception of the main, big piece that holds the tiles, caps, small cards and the miscellaneous bits with the dice. They all fit in the box together and some even nest together.

Everything prints well and doesn't require much finish work with the exception of the nested parts. The top tray that holds the setup directions and faction tokens has support material and might need a little bit of sanding (I remodeled the part that sets in the box underneath it, but I didn't reprint it as I sanded mine down to fit). The special tray SHOULD fit as it was redesigned, but since I also sanded this down to fit, I didn't reprint it.

Some of these pieces take ages to print, and since they're right at the limit of my printer's print bed, I did most of them individually & it took me a week of printing (and some reprinting). That being said, I also printed at .15 layer height with a 5 outline perimeter skirt in order to mitigate curling. This didn't work well, so be sure to use your favorite bed adhesive. I also used 4 layer top layer heights so that I would minimize that thing that happens near the edges of the print where the flat stuff falls in between the infill near the edges of the print. I'm new to 3D printing and this is my first original work so I dunno what that's called.

Hope this helps you in your Fallout Board Game organization, and hopefully it doesn't lighten your wallet too much with how much plastic is used... don't say I didn't warn you =)

title: Hobby knife cutting and carving blade model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a model of a hobby knife cutting and carving blade. You may probably never want to print it with plastic filament, but it may be useful when you design something that hosts a blade.

Note that this model was designed by measuring an actual blade, not by following a specification, so it may not be accurate. There are several types of blades that differ in shape and size, so this file models the one I could by in the nearest shop (I attached the photos of the box for reference).

title: Solitude - singular algebraic surface
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Solitude, a singular algebraic surface of degree four. This is the set of real points for which x^2*y*z +x*y^2+y^3+y^3*z-x^2*z^2 = 0.

Has two holes, and two singular lines, one of which exists nakedly in the voids in the surface!

Provided are three files:

  • solitude_thickened.stl -- has the normal vectors fixed, and is thickened for printing.
  • solitude_raw.stl -- raw triangulation coming from Bertini_real. Since the program works in arbitrary dimensions, I make no effort to control normals from it -- they don't exist for 4- and higher-dimensional surfaces, but instead a tangent space which is not immediately useful for 3d printing. Hence, the surface was thickened in Blender, before being passed through Microsoft's 3D Builder to fix internal geometry. This version is not directly suitable for 3d printing.
  • input -- the Bertini_real input file used to compute it.

Computed with a Numerical Algebraic Geometry program I wrote, called Bertini_real and printed as part of my long-term project to reproduce Herwig Hauser's gallery of algebraic surface ray-traces in my own gallery of 3d prints. The ACM ToMS algorithm number is 976; the major published paper is DOI 10.1145/3056528 with several others preceding. Bertini_real implements the implicit function theorem for algebraic surfaces and curves in any (reasonable) number of variables.

See also, my Thingiverse collection of algebraic surfaces.

VF = Left Front (Danish: Venstre Foran)
HF = Right Front (Danish: Højre Foran)
VB = Left Rear (Danish: Venstre Bag)
HB = Right Rear (Danish: Højre Bag)
So for non-Danish speaking folks, use this as inspiration....

This LED lamp uses the same basic geometry as https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2699705, but the layers are taller and are rounded instead of having sharp edges. As a result it takes a bit longer to print; this part printed in 25 2/4 hours using a layer height of 0.200 mm and a print speed of 80 mm/sec.

The lamp is designed for an LED "puck" light. Battery operated lights are about $4 each; simply do a web search for "LED puck light" to find several sources. This blog page tells where you can get wall powered lights that are brighter and that work very well: http://birkbinnard.com/blog/wall-powered-led-lights/.

description.text: I was going to sleep the other night, I had an overnight print going, and I noticed the LCD on my Anet A8 was very bright, so for the time being i taped some playing cards to the LCD screen, however this was unsightly, so when i woke up the next morning I sketched up a design and then created it in Fusion 360, it took a little bit of trial and error and the file you are getting is actually better than the one I have attached on my printer, I just did not feel like printing another one because the one I attached is good enough. I would suggest you use a filament color other than white because the light still shows through this somewhat, but if you only have white like me then tape something opaque to the inside of the cover, that way the light does not shine through. Make sure your bed is covered in hairspray or whatever you use to make prints stick because the cover itself likes to warp if it is not properly adhered to the bed. Any ideas to improve this design will be welcome, if you have constructive criticism I will respond

description.text: This is a coil designed to maximize the distance that ants have to travel to reach their food while fitting within a medium-sized formicarium. If you have a large enough ant colony, you should be able to see them form a trail along the coil. It is composed of a base, a top platform, and a number of “ribs” which make up the main part of the coil. The more ribs you include, the taller the coil will be. There is also a detachable hexagon piece that fits within the top platform and a 12 gauge aluminum wire that supports the coil. The hexagon should be laser cut from acrylic if possible, but I have also included an STL for it in case you don’t have access to a laser cutter. I got the wire from the Home Depot and it can also be found on Amazon. https://www.amazon.com/Beadsmith-DA2602-Aluminum-Gauge-Coil-Silver/dp/B003LTGS4E/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1512932964&sr=8-3&keywords=12+gauge+aluminum+wire

Decide how tall you want the coil to be and figure out how many ribs it will take. A 16 rib coil is about 85mm tall and a 10 rib coil is about 65, but these numbers are very approximate because it can be stretched or compressed to a degree.
Print the number of ribs you want, along with the base and the wire coiler. If you don’t have a laser cutter, also print the hexagon here. These should all be printed without support.
Print the top platform separately with support.
Cut an appropriate length of wire without kinking it and clamp one end to the base of the wire coiler with the vice-grips. Use your thumb to exert enough pressure on the wire to begin coiling it around the groove and be careful not to let it slip.
If you want to make a tall coil you might have to coil the wire around the coiler a second time. Release the wire and re-clamp it at the base of the coiler again so that you can continue coiling.
Once coil is long enough, release it and use a pair of pliers to cut off the end of the wire that was in the vice grips since it is probably not coiled perfectly.
Use the pliers to force the wire into the base and then add ribs one at a time. Snap them into place with the pliers.
After you have added all the ribs, cut the remaining wire so that it will fit into the groove on the top platform. Snap the top platform into place with the pliers.
Optional: Use super glue or acrylic cement to glue all the ribs together.
Place the hexagon in the top platform.

To make this you need automatically flashing RGB LEDs and 3V tablet battery like CR2032 or similar. Also, you should use 1.5x0.2 mm solar busbar wire ribbon for making a switch.

This thing included eleven different models with switch integrated. Just print and assembly.

For assembling you need a small piece of 1.75 mm filament about 1 cm length. Also needed two copper busbar wire about 2 cm length for making contact group. The filament of 4 mm length inserts into the switch_main part to make rotation limiter. After that insert busbar in a slit and turn down. Place busbar into side holes and bend. Insert switch_main with busbar into switch_ring For complete assembly insert filament through the holes in switch_main and switch_stopper part.

description.text:
I designed a c170 holder before for my prusa i3 mk2 but was not happy with it anymore.

After having a closer look at the machine I found that the front screws holding the heat bed in place do not reach trough the hole in the frame, so it would be a good place.

The system now is lighter, more robust and does not reach out to the front.

To use it you have to take apart you c170 (only 8 philipps head screws) and clip it in the case that you printed. The whole arm needs to be secured on one of the front print bed srews. What you will need is one M3 12mm screw. Also one screw for the hinge (again M3, size whatever you have around).

Here is what the view is like:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=em81So1BgJA

A simple design to help celebrate "Festivus" (For the Rest of Us), it's a small table top model that can be printed in small printers, the design is in sections and it can be made as tall as you like with or without hooks if you decide to hang lights around it, also the festivus pole does not have a top but i made one just in case you want to put one on it, make sure you use super glue to stick the parts together, enjoy!

The top and middle sections require supports.

A little on Festivus:

The non-commercial holiday's celebration, as depicted on Seinfeld, occurs on December 23 and includes a Festivus dinner, an unadorned aluminum Festivus pole, practices such as the "Airing of Grievances" and "Feats of Strength", and the labeling of easily explainable events as "Festivus miracles".

title: Y-Axis Belt Block for Anet A8 or AM8

description.text:
This is a replacement for the brittle acrylic straps that hold the belt on the bottom of the bed for the Y-axis. This also helps the belt geometry by lowering the belt a few mm to bring it closer in line with the pulley. The belt ends just slip into the block halves and out thru the hole. When loose just enough for the belts to be moved but still catch you and simply push the belts into the block and they will somewhat ratchet into place then tighten the block to secure them. I think you can probably get away with using most any material for this block. I have 50+ hours on mine so far printing at over 5000 mm/min without any signs of wear and its just made out of PLA+.

This is sized for the bolt pattern on a 2017 standard Anet A8 bed support frame. Since these kits can vary make sure and just your hole alignment before you go thru the hassle of taking it apart just in case yours is different than mine. If its the same it will be a perfect fit with no mods needed to printer or the part.

Anet A8/AM8

comments.text: The hole pattern and screws are the originals from the anet Y Carriage (which of course also fits the upgraded RepRap Champion Y carriage). It’s been too long ago that I made it to remember off the top of my head the specifics but you can always measure it from the stl file. Shouldn’t have any need to though as it’s the standard hole pattern for the A8 & A6 Y carriages. If you have either it’s a bolt on replacement for the crappy acrylic straps. Just use your originals with it or any hardware that fits in the holes. It doesn’t require anything special to bolt the block to the carriage

Be sure to print the parts with the pins etc pointing up.
And the 4 small stoppers for the bearings must be printed with the convex surface downwards.
They have small risers to press on the center parts of the bearings and those must point up otherwise it might not print so good!

I also used a little short m3 screw from an old computer as the lock screw as you can see in one of the pictures. :)

Works as a charm so get printing now!

And yeah I forgot to mention, the pins for the bearings are slightly shorter then the width of the bearings, and that is to assure good pressure on the center of the bearings.
just use like 15mm screws and it will be no problem :)!

title: (beta) iPhone X Flexible Case with buttons

description.text:
An iPhone X case with built in buttons to be printed with flexible filament. I designed it according to Apple's official design guidelines so it should be 100% correct. The case is pretty thick so it'll protect your phone very well.
I also have a case with cutouts if you prefer that and I also have cases for the iPhone 5/5S/SE and 6S/7/8.

You might have to re-align the file on the buildplate in your slicer.

If you printed this case, please post a picture or review of it in the "Made" section and give some feedback, that way I can update the design to make it better.

Edit: I temporarily deleted the file because I am fixing the buttons. Someone said they're not responsive enough so I am working on it. In the meantime I took away the download file so people don't print a faulty case. You can still print the one without buttons :)

author: aciim

description.text:
suport for lithophanies 80x80x1.6 (round model) and 106.5x80x1.6mm with two hot candles.

To print the media put 25% of filling and at least 5 lines of borders. I tried to print in concentric mode for the pattern of the top / bottom and the result is really nice, I advise you. Set the support at 15 or 20% is enough.
I've also created a two-piece suport to make it easier to print, but print outs are more difficult to remove.

To print lithophanies of quality with Cura3 import photos directly in .jpg format.
In the dialog box that appears, enter the following parameters;
Height: 1.6
-Base: 0.2
-Width: 106.5
the darker is higher

the lithophanies printed in vertical have really a superior quality but implies to have a nozzle in 0.2 or to adjust the base to a minimum of 0.4 (diameter of the nozzle) which imputes very much the final rendering (transparency of the photos). I advise you to print horizontally if you have a nozzle in 0.4 and vertical if you have 0.2.
Before printing make sure your print is 1.6mm thick (Z axis), check in "Layer" display mode to make sure there are no holes and there are at least two full base layers (smooth) ....
Set 0.1 mm layer, 0.1 mm initial layers, 100% filling. I will share very soon a special lithophany profile that works very well and is proven.
Once printed, place the smooth lithophane plates (printed side towards the candles), light the candles without fear and admire your work.

I will soon post a video tutorial, printing lithophany.

sorry for my language, but I'm french, do not speak English very well and work with Google translator ....

En Français:

suport pour lithophanies 80x80x1.6 (modèle rond) et 106.5x80x1.6mm avec deux bougies chauffantes.

Pour imprimer le support mettez 25% de remplissage et au moins 5 lignes de bordures. J'ai essayé d'imprimer en mode concentrique pour le motif du dessus/dessous et le résultat est vraiment sympa, je vous le conseil. Réglez les support a 15 ou 20% ça suffit.
J'ai créé aussi un suport en deux partie à emboiter pour que l'impression soit plus facile mais les suports d'impressions sont plus difficile à retirer.

Pour imprimer des lithophanies de qualitées avec Cura3 importer des photos directement au format .jpg.
Dans la boîte de dialogue qui apparaît, entrez les paramètres suivants;
Hauteur: 1.6
-Base: 0,2
-Largeur: 106.5
le plus sombre est plus élevé

les lithophanies imprimées en vertical ont vraiment une qualité supérieure mais implique d'avoir une buse en 0.2 ou d'ajuster la base à un minimum de 0.4 (diamètre de la buse) ce qui impute beaucoup le rendu final (transparence des photos). Je vous conseille d'imprimer horizontalement si vous avez une buse en 0.4 et verticale si vous avez 0.2.
Avant d'imprimer assurez-vous que votre impression est de 1,6 mm d'épaisseur (axe Z), vérifiez en mode d'affichage "couche" pour vous assurer qu'il n'y a pas de trous et qu'il y a au moins deux couches de base pleines (lisses) ....
Réglez 0,1 mm de couche, 0,1 mm de couches initiales, remplissage à 100%. Je partagerai trés bientôt un profile spécial lithophanie qui fonctionne très bien et à fait ses preuves.
Une fois imprimées, placez les plaques en lithophane lisses (côté imprimé vers les bougies), allumez les bougies sans crainte et admirez votre travail.

Je posterai prochainement un video tutorial, d'impression de lithophanie.

description.text:
Sometimes on Christmas bauble, you need an electrical switch to turn on a light. Here a small and simple switch.

For assembling you need a small piece of 1.75 mm filament about 1 cm length. Also needed two copper busbar wire about 2 cm length for making contact group. The filament of 4 mm length inserts into the switch_main part to make rotation limiter. After that insert busbar in a slit and turn down. Switch_ring model should be integrated into your toy. Place busbar into side holes and bend. Insert switch_main with busbar into switch_ring For complete assembly insert filament through the holes in switch_main and switch_stopper part.

Use a CRxxxx Battery Holder Generator to make a holder for battery power supply.

This switch is used at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2719598

print_settings.Notes:: Scale model parts to 550%. This is just a test so not all parts will fit together.

description.text:
Seeing that No one has made a printable 3D Versionn of the Merlin V12 I decide to see what I can do. The main source for the model is from Steen Winther on Grabcad. Link to his Model (https://grabcad.com/library/olsryd-v12-merlin-engine-on-test-stand-1).
If all works as planned it will be a complete working motor with all internal parts turning ect.
I'm still a long way from done, this includes all gears from the gearbox to the supercharger, camshafts, crank, rods ect.
Still trying to Find a decent scale for metal bearings to fit in the original places.

Some parts are not labeled correctly, will get the full parts list up as soon as I'm done.

Will update as I go on and add more photo's off my build.
Expected size will be close to 1/5 scale

Update V1.01

First Piston and Rod printed, need to slow down the speed a little bit to say 0.15 for the finer detail. Still looks Epic!!

Block on the printing bed now so will update as soon as its done!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20/30%

Notes:

Scale model parts to 550%. This is just a test so not all parts will fit together.

Update V1.02

Testing out the Spitfire prop and spinner on the engine,
also working on the parts inventory and color for every part with layer hight and infill.
Should have all done in the next few days but will keep posting updates as I go on. Let me know what you guys think off the 4 blade or should I go with the 3 blade Config.

Partial Assembly

I made 2 options for printing the Block, The one is a 3 part print and the other one is a single piece. Little less fuss getting everything together.
Most off the engine is done except for the moving parts, Just want to get most off it together to see what fits and what not.
Had to redo the intake manifold and the exhaust manifolds as they did not want to print at all.

There are also 2 types off engine stands, a short version and a long version. My printer kept messing the large one up as it got to the top.
Will update the images on top and on the new parts list as soon as I'm done with most off the build. So far it all looks very well on a scale of 550 in Cura. Can go bigger but will not advice that.

Nice model, but both my friend and myself seem to have an issue with missing sections in the towers when sliced...
Also, you could probably do with including a file with the rock base and castle together without the box - the separate castle is unprintable as it would need supports, but there's too many little bits floating around to use them.
comments.author: ReBorne

comments.text: I'm seeing the same missing sections in Cura.  There's nothing wrong with the model or the slicer ... just some of the sections are too skinny for your printer's resolution.  Specifically with the towers, the missing areas are hollowed out sections with windows cut through them ... the remaining window frames are too narrow/skinny for the slicer to be able to build them.  If you drop a solid cylinder inside (with Blender) then it solves that issue.  Same problem with the existing columns for the bridge sections, too narrow for my printer, so I needed to add in some cubes.  You could also print the model at a larger scale, which would make those skinny sections thick enough for the slicer to include them.  If I'm able to print it with my own printer, I'll share my results.

print_settings.Notes:: Not sure whether I'd print the plungers in PLA if you use a heated bed, however it might still be ok.

description.text:
I started following the Precision Piezo thread on RepRap forums a while ago when some people (DjDemonD, Moriquendi) started coming up with brilliant ideas about using piezo disks as very sensitive switches/probes for bed probing. They later evolved into something called Precision Piezo (www.precisionpiezo.co.uk)

I had one of the earlier Piezo boards by Moriquendi and initially tried the hotend mount, however I found it really difficult to dial in...and the results wouldn't be consistent (it was my own DIY solution though).

So I went for the underbed method of mounting the piezo disks...and the result is amazing.
The idea came from DjDemonD ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2446460 )

Here is a video of the whole system in action (running grid leveling), you can see the mounts around 00:30 : https://photos.app.goo.gl/cz5BhU3H960tHeKa2

I designed the mounts for my 22cm diameter bed heater, however these mounts should work with most round (although not necessarily ) beds. This is intended for 20mm piezo disks.

The model consists of 3 parts - the bed mount, cap and plunger, with the piezo disk sitting between the mount and the cap. I did not bother gluing the cap to the mount because it worked quite well without it, as well as I could adjust things if required (e.g. flip disks, etc).

For a delta you'll need 3 of each part, as well as 3 M3 bolts (I used 12mm) and some T nuts.

The bed rests comfortably on the plungers with a tiny gap between the mounts and the bed so as not to limit the bed vertical movement while probing.

Make sure the plungers can get through the hole in the caps easily.

Printed with 3 outlines and 3 base/top layers from PETG. I would probably want to avoid using PLA if using a heated bed, although it might still work ok.

Printer:

Micromake D1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

Not sure whether I'd print the plungers in PLA if you use a heated bed, however it might still be ok.

description.text:
A vise (german: Schraubstock).

At first, you have to screw together the Schraubstock_Backe and Schraubstock_Backe_Gegenstück parts on the rail in Schraubstock_Base. Then you have to glue two pieces: a) The U10Mutter part into Schraubstock_Base and b) The Schraubstock_Backe_Schraubenhalter onto Schraubstock_Backe (after you placed the U10_Schraubstock screw into Schraubstock_Backe). Ideally, you fix the Schraubstock_Backe_Schraubenhalter with two clamps and then close the vise so that there is a slight tension on the U10Mutter so it gets pushed into its slot.

title: i3 y Belt Holder with Tensioner

description.text:
Belt holder with integrated tensioner suitable for y axis on Prusa i3 clones.

The tensioning is reliable and two times stronger than tensioners with are acting on the idler.

The hight is enlarged to eliminate the triangulation in the belt geometry, witch avoids wobble in the belt tension. This might prevent your belt from becoming baggy and ensures that the tension is constant over the entire distance.

The spacing of the holes are matched with the spacing on the initial design of the y sled (the frog). The spacing on the frog is 45mm. This holder has 4 Holes with 22.5mm spacing.

The Belt is just pushed into the slots in the belt holder and the block. The block is then pushed into the pocket in the holder and tensioned with an M3x40mm screw and a nut

I use it with my 2-3-4-5-Owl

=> See also my other Prusa i3 reworks in my Collection

=> This Part is also used in my Prusa i3 master reworks

author: GhoMa

description.text:
Build for simple cleaning a 5.25" floppy disc. Its not perfect, hopefully others can build on the idea or the design.

Problem with the 5.25" is the lack of a dedicated protected socket for rotation, you have to clam down on both sides for a rotation. This also means, that any cleaning of the discs has to be done very lightly, as the pressure by the cleaning-cloth on the disc read-window works against the pressure applied when rotating the knob for rotating the disc.

Can be used as just the knob or with the added support. The support could arguably use an even better support for discs, so that it holds down the disc much better. The raised area on the support is meant for a cutout cloth for slowly applied cleaning. Hold on to the support while lightly pressing down on the disc on the up side.

Please note, 3d printed surfaces clammed hard on your discs, can damage the discs over time. add a layer of thin rubber if possible on the surfaces that touch the disc.

I dont know much about print settings; i use DaVinci XYZWare on default PLA settings. Cant imagine much problems with this design.

5x M6 wing nut
8x 3x20 spax screw (or other small wood screws)
1x table clamp (maybe not that easy to come by, I used "50mm ijzer tafelklem")
2 pieces of 18x27mm pine wood ("vuren geschaafd 18x27mm")

Lamp fittings:
1x E14 threaded lamp holder
1x In line cord switch (optional)
1x Electric power plug
3m of fancy electric cord

Assembly:
Screw 2x part A to both ends of a piece of wood, facing the same direction
Screw 1x part A and 1x part B to both ends of the other piece of wood, facing opposite directions
Table mount: assemble part A + part C + part D
Lamp holder: assemble part A + part C + part E
Middle lamp hinge: assemble part A + part B

NOTICE
Every hinge can be adjusted. Be sure to loosen the wing nut far enough so the hinge can rotate freely. Do not use force!
Only use LED light bulbs. Other light bulbs tend to get too hot and could deform the printed parts.

print_settings.Notes:: These surfaces are generally challenging to print.  Rotate, and use careful support.  I use Simplify3D for the manual support placement feature.

title: Calyx - singular algebraic surface
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Calyx, a singular algebraic surface of degree five. This is the set of real points for which 

x^2+y^2*z^3 - z^4 = 0.

Has a point singularity on a cusp-line singularity.

I have provided these files:

  • Calyx_blocky_xy.stl -- has the normal vectors fixed, and is thickened for printing.
  • calyx_medium_smooth_xy.stl -- the blocky version, ran through the sampler module for bertini_real.
  • calyx_raw_blocky.stl -- raw triangulation coming from Bertini_real. Since the program works in arbitrary dimensions, I make no effort to control normals from it -- they don't exist for 4- and higher-dimensional surfaces, but instead a tangent space which is not immediately useful for 3d printing. Hence, the surface was thickened in Blender, before being passed through Microsoft's 3D Builder to fix internal geometry. The raw versions are not directly suitable for 3d printing.
  • calyx_raw_medium_smooth.stl -- infinitely thin, but ran through sampler with medium tolerances.
  • calyx_raw_refined.stl -- infinitely thin, ran through sampler with fairly tight tolerances.
  • input -- the Bertini_real input file used to compute it.

This surface was sampled before I implemented cyclenumber > 1 sampling, so the surface is undersampled near critical points and singularities.

Computed with a Numerical Algebraic Geometry program I wrote, called Bertini_real and printed as part of my long-term project to reproduce Herwig Hauser's gallery of algebraic surface ray-traces in my own gallery of 3d prints. The ACM ToMS algorithm number is 976; the major published paper is DOI 10.1145/3056528 with several others preceding. Bertini_real implements the implicit function theorem for algebraic surfaces and curves in any (reasonable) number of variables.

See also, my Thingiverse collection of algebraic surfaces.

author: Fugazi123

description.text:
This is a collection of upgrades to the printer. At this point I stopped in the tuning. Actually, nothing special, just my vision of all known things and some third-party designs.

Spoolholder - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1724880 I drilled 8mm holes in the bottom.
Cute lamp - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27062 with GU5.3 holder and lamp
I forgot, where I found the filament cleaner, but it is something like this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1692395

Also used:
T8 spring loaded nut - 2 pc. for "antiwobling". Be careful, need to order pitch 2mm lead 8mm. Actually, you can screw it upside down as I did, but for whose who want to hide springs, here is "antiwobling" versions of X-shafts holders.
Bearings MR148ZZ - 4 pieces for fixing lead screws.
Wattmeter PZEM-021 - for power casing
6mm toggle mts-101 2pin - for lamp.
80mm fan + grill - PCB cooling.
SD - extension
Two 2-GT 16 teeth pulleys - for tensioners
M3 nut - for X-tensioner.
and various metalware.

The printer stands on a sheet of expanded polyethylene foam for less noise. In this setup, there are no internal stresses, so I dont need to fix it to some kind of a basis.

I dont give the power supply casing, because my unit died very quickly and I replaced it with a cheap 8 or 10 amps, I dont remember exactly. The bed is heated with a silicon heater that is connected to 220 volts via a relay(On the link datasheet for my relay. You can use something similar) that is triggered by 12 volt heated bed plug on PCB. By the way, the heating time has decreased at least twice. I recommend to everyone.
Z-axis adjustment screw screwed into the lock nut that I glued to the left x-axis holder, because I don't like the solution with a spring.

All mechanical parts such as motor mounts, X-axis holders and tensioners was printed with PET-G without brim, 35% infill.
Spring guides - ABS 100% infill.
PCB casing and SD-Holder - SBS with support 100% infill.

The print quality, of course, dramatically depends on speed, so I calibrated all holes by drilling it with appropriate drill. For X-shafts holes I used 8.1 drill.

And the major advice - dont over-tighten the heated bed springs.

I also advise you to put the Y-motor on a standard mount.

Iam tired of damn experiments in ali, so some links may not work. See pictures.
my son asked to do this for his LEGO

author: kleinerELM

title: Calypso - singular algebraic surface
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Calypso, a singular algebraic surface of degree three. This is the set of real points for which 

x^2 + y^2*z - z^2 = 0.

Has a single point singularity.

I have provided these files:

  • calypso_smooth_thickened.stl -- has the normal vectors fixed, and is thickened for printing.
  • calypso_blocky_thickened.stl -- the blocky version, good for printing
  • calypso_blocky_xy.stl -- raw triangulation coming from Bertini_real. Since the program works in arbitrary dimensions, I make no effort to control normals from it -- they don't exist for 4- and higher-dimensional surfaces, but instead a tangent space which is not immediately useful for 3d printing. Hence, the surface was thickened in Blender, before being passed through Microsoft's 3D Builder to fix internal geometry. The raw versions are not directly suitable for 3d printing.
  • calypso_smooth_xy.stl -- infinitely thin, ran through sampler with fairly tight tolerances.
  • input -- the Bertini_real input file used to compute it.

This surface was sampled before I implemented cyclenumber > 1 sampling, so the surface is undersampled near critical points and singularities.

Computed with a Numerical Algebraic Geometry program I wrote, called Bertini_real and printed as part of my long-term project to reproduce Herwig Hauser's gallery of algebraic surface ray-traces in my own gallery of 3d prints. The ACM ToMS algorithm number is 976; the major published paper is DOI 10.1145/3056528 with several others preceding. Bertini_real implements the implicit function theorem for algebraic surfaces and curves in any (reasonable) number of variables.

These surfaces are generally challenging to print. Rotate, and use careful support. I use Simplify3D for the manual support placement feature. These surfaces are also very tiny in scale (arbitrary units and math and all) so require significant upsizing.

See also, my Thingiverse collection of algebraic surfaces.

title: Volkswagen switch cover SD card holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I love listening to music while driving and I listen to a variety of genres. I decided to use several SD cards with different kind of genres but I could not find a good place in my car to put them. Then I saw that there are a couple of blank removable switch covers in which something can be fitted. I this case an SD card holder.

I used the two most right covers so the radius is on the right side. I drive a VW Scirocco but I recon that the same switch bank is also used in other VW models.

Keep in mind that PLA material does not cope well with high temperatures. It becomes weak above 60°C to 65°C. This design does not have to hold anything like a cup- or phone holder, but I cannot guarantee that it will stay intact after a hot day.

author: layershifter

title: Columpius - smooth algebraic surface
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Columpius, a smooth algebraic surface of degree four. This is the set of real points for which 

x^3*y+x*z^3+y^3*z+z^3+7*z^2+5*z = 0.

Has two holes!

I have provided these files:

  • columpius_smooth_thickened.stl -- has the normal vectors fixed, and is thickened for printing. I should re-do this one, because there are artificial self-intersections near one of the holes. I now know how to do this step better.
  • Columpius_Blocky_Xy_thickened.stl -- the blocky version, good for printing
  • columpius_raw_blocky_xy.stl -- raw triangulation coming from Bertini_real. Since the program works in arbitrary dimensions, I make no effort to control normals from it -- they don't exist for 4- and higher-dimensional surfaces, but instead a tangent space which is not immediately useful for 3d printing. Hence, the surface was thickened in Blender, before being passed through Microsoft's 3D Builder to fix internal geometry. The raw versions are not directly suitable for 3d printing.
  • columpius_raw_smooth.stl -- infinitely thin, ran through sampler with fairly tight tolerances.
  • input -- the Bertini_real input file used to compute it.

This surface was sampled before I implemented cyclenumber > 1 sampling, so the surface is undersampled near critical points and singularities.

Computed with a Numerical Algebraic Geometry program I wrote, called Bertini_real and printed as part of my long-term project to reproduce Herwig Hauser's gallery of algebraic surface ray-traces in my own gallery of 3d prints. The ACM ToMS algorithm number is 976; the major published paper is DOI 10.1145/3056528 with several others preceding. Bertini_real implements the implicit function theorem for algebraic surfaces and curves in any (reasonable) number of variables.

These surfaces are generally challenging to print. Rotate, and use careful support. I use Simplify3D for the manual support placement feature. These surfaces are also very tiny in scale (arbitrary units and math and all) so require significant upsizing.

See also, my Thingiverse collection of algebraic surfaces.

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

238C - 17mmS - retract: 20mmS / 0.5mm

The Siplace 141121 feeder is designed for 32mm tapes and comes with a tape width reducer, which can be screwed into positions for 24mm (and sometimes also for 16mm) tapes.
The original part is made of metal, but since it has to be removed completely for 32mm tapes it can get lost.
It is theoretically possible to run this feeder with smaller tapes, so I've added the option for extraspace set to be 1 or higher to reduce in 8mm steps.

I haven't printed this part yet.

title: Cube - smooth algebraic surface
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Cube, a smooth algebraic surface of degree six. This is the set of real points for which 

x^6 + y^6 + z^6 -1 = 0.

Is everywhere smooth! Not an actual cube; you get a cube if you replace the 6 in the equation by infinity, but then it's impossible to compute...

I have provided these files:

  • Cube_fixed_Blocky.stl -- has the normal vectors fixed.
  • Cube_fixed_Med_Smooth.stl -- the blocky version, normal vectors fixed
  • cube_raw_blocky.stl -- raw triangulation coming from Bertini_real. Since the program works in arbitrary dimensions, I make no effort to control normals from it -- they don't exist for 4- and higher-dimensional surfaces, but instead a tangent space which is not immediately useful for 3d printing. The raw versions are not directly suitable for 3d printing.
  • cube_raw_med_smooth.stl --ran through sampler with fairly loose tolerances. Incorrect normals.
  • input -- the Bertini_real input file used to compute it.

This surface was sampled before I implemented cyclenumber > 1 sampling, so the surface is undersampled near critical points and singularities. It's also deliberately low-res.

Computed with a Numerical Algebraic Geometry program I wrote, called Bertini_real and printed as part of my long-term project to reproduce Herwig Hauser's gallery of algebraic surface ray-traces in my own gallery of 3d prints. The ACM ToMS algorithm number is 976; the major published paper is DOI 10.1145/3056528 with several others preceding. Bertini_real implements the implicit function theorem for algebraic surfaces and curves in any (reasonable) number of variables.

These surfaces are generally challenging to print. Rotate, and use careful support. I use Simplify3D for the manual support placement feature. These surfaces are also very tiny in scale (arbitrary units and math and all) so require significant upsizing.

See also, my Thingiverse collection of algebraic surfaces.

title: CTC Prusa i3 Bowden Conversion using stock parts

description.text: This is a remix... ish of another bowden extruder, however this one uses the bearing that comes with the printer and is mounted directly to the top left z axis plate. It has been working very well for me thus far and looks pretty streamline attached to the printer. I went ahead and also included the right z top plate to go with it. I did not make the hole for the threaded rods the size needed for a top bearing since I wouldnt trust those rods to be straight and a bearing would just cause z wobble at that point. The only parts you should need are a few m3 screws of varying length, one of which is a count-sink screw that goes under the tensioner. You could use a spring on the tensioner of you like, but there hasnt been a need as I have set the dimensions so that you just get it snug and it grips the filament just right. If I get around to disassembling the part again then I will post the screw lengths needed.

comments.text: Surprised it works with no adjustment for force on the filament.  First thing I had to do for printing on this printer was upgrade the extruder to the spring loaded one.
comments.author: joebywan

comments.text: You can add a spring if desired and was my original plan.  When I printed it and tested it however it just didn't need it and I didn't feel like making a special trip to the hardware store just for an apparently unnecessary spring.  The feeding holes are aligned so that the teeth dig in before before the clamp is even applied and since the feed holes are also very close to the gear itself there is minimal room for the filament to flex. In truth, it almost works without the clamp at all.  Because of this I don't have the clamp tightened all the way, just lightly snug.  I could easily remove some material to give a little more room to clamp down harder.

title: Security camera mount to gang box

description.text:
Needed a way to mount my Laview security cameras to 1 gang switch boxes. Designed to press fit a 5/16 size (7.77 mm) nut on the underside. Insert nuts, attach to the outlet box, then screw the camera into the press fit screws. You have to measure the appropriate length bolt to use based on your brand camera as it cannot project beyond the base of the mount.

The mount also serves to cover the arch at the camera base used to run wires out the side which I did not want.

(Optional) One of my cameras needed to sit down a bit lower to clear an obstacle so created the spacer to go with it. Sink it into the build plate when slicing to get a reduced height.

title: CTC Prusa i3 Z axis motor mounts

description.text: This is again, kind of a remix of pepcowboys idea with the motor mounts. The dimensions did not work with mine so I started from scratch and used the idea of them to move forward. On mine the mounts sit perfectly flush with the bottom of the laser cut board so that there is extra support and the weight of the motors cannot bend the plywood at all nor the torque effect send vibrations. I did style it a little just because, who doesnt like a cool looking printer? The z axis limit switch mount is separate to allow a cleaner print of the motor mounts. I just super glued the 2 perfectly flat surfaces(since the top of the mount and bottom of the limit switch mount are on the printbed side while being printed) and it works great. There is no real force being applied to the limit switch mount so this has worked out very well for a clean looking part in the end.

author: GunnerAlpha

print_settings.Notes:: Must print with raft.  Print one first to be certain that the part is usable in your print settings before doing many at once.

description.text:
Must print with raft or you will spend forever trying to clean the ball bearings.

If you don't use raft, the bearings will be impossible to print.

I printed a storage unit stand for the PSU and the drawers required 8x 625 bearings. Since this is not a build that requires heavy use of the bearings, I decided to try making one in fusion 360. It's basicallly a 16mm round, 5mm wide with a 5mm hole in the middle.

This was used in the print I made from : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2612534

Depending on your printer and material, may still need to file the hole in middle to ensure you have 5mm there. Once you do that, pushing in the middle should cause the tiny adhesion to the ball bearings to pop and the bearing now moves.

Note, don't even try this for fast regular movements that require a real bearing, but it should be useful for things like drawers.
